post_text: Today begins the Census Bowl for Coosa County and 31 other counties with the lowest Census participation percentage. Because of the participation we received on Saturday, turning in those "yellow sheets", we hope to be the winners of $65,000 for our school system. This CONTEST will continue through the remainder of the month. To help us SECURE the $65,000, we are asking all families to seek additional families who have not registered for the census. Please message us their phone numbers and we will take care of the rest. #TEAMCOOSACOUNTS #weareallimportant #wecandothistogether #loveourschoolsystem

post_text: This week is the first week in school. There will be several Google Meets set up in order to educate parents, students and others on how things will work and also introducing everyone to the platforms Google Classroom or SeeSaw. Students will be assigned their reading and math diagnostic to complete as well. Teachers will be giving individual further directions as well pertaining to their classes specifically. Please do not let this confuse you. Teachers may have given future dates out for assignments but school begins this week.
shared_text:

August 30 at 7:53 PM ¬∑

Coosa County Schools begin tomorrow! We are ready for this new venture! We will be available to assist with trouble shooting. Contact the schools.

There will be several Google Meets set up in order to educate parents, students and others on how things will work and also introducing everyone to the platforms Google Classroom or SeeSaw. Students will be assigned their reading and math diagnostic to complete as well. Teachers will be giving individual further directions as well pertaining to their classes specifically. Please do not let this confuse you. Teachers may have given future dates out for assignments but school begins this week.

post_text: Saturday's Student Success Day Event
text: Saturday's Student Success Day Event

post_text: https://www.facebook.com/CentralCoosaElementaryPTO/posts/1372913032918506
shared_text:
Central Coosa Elementary PTO
August 11 at 3:06 PM ¬∑

On Saturday, August 29th, 2020, we will have a very important day for all Central Elementary and Central High School families to turn in paperwork, receive school supplies, Chromebooks, school lunches, and schedules. You will need to report to the back of the school and bring your completed paperwork at the following times:

If the last name of one or both parents begins with A-C, please arrive at 8:00 a.m.
If the last name of one or both parents begins with D-G, please arrive at 9:00 a.m.
If the last name of one or both parents begins with H-J. please arrive at 10:00 a.m.
If the last name of one or both parents begins with K-M, please arrive at 12:00 p.m.
If the last name of one or both parents begins with N-S, please arrive at 1:00 p.m.
If the last name of one or both parents begins with T-Z, please arrive at 2:00 p.m.

Thank you and Go Cougars!

post_text:
Love the POSITIVITY we all have been witnessing by faculty. Here's a perspective of one...
https://www.facebook.com/1826566765/posts/10214486843964656/
shared_text:
LeslieAnn Ward Wells
August 22 at 12:32 AM ¬∑

Coosa parents...no stresses. The teachers will be leading lessons live and recorded. And Kindergarten teachers are also sending home COUGAR binders with no-screen required activities. We have been learning the platforms and preparing lessons. This is NOT the quarantine learning packets of the spring! This is real learning. Kids will interact with teachers. We will be having whole group lessons led by all three of us. Then we will have individual small groups with our own homeroom and 1-1 with students and their parents. We will have imbedded brain breaks. Each of us have sent our emails and Remind messages among phone calls and letters. We are a team-teachers, parents, students. (Many of the above statements apply to all grades K-6.)

Stay positive and be prepared for learning, communication and fun too! Is this ideal? No! Will there be glitches? Yes.

We miss our babies and their sticky fingers and dirty faces but it is necessary at this time to do remote learning for the health and safety of our students, staff and families.

Anyone who wonders why we at Coosa are going virtual only need to talk to teachers at other schools who have been brick and mortar. As a member of several teacher groups, I can tell you they are sending kids and staff home for exposure and outbreaks. Just because you haven‚Äôt seen the outbreaks on the news/social media doesn‚Äôt mean it isn‚Äôt happening.

The positive is that even when school becomes ‚Äúnormal‚Äù again, students will never have an excuse for not being able to know about assignments because we will be experts in this little thing called remote learning. No more 20-30 absences in a school year. Students will be able to work from home when they have the flu or a cold or the ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel like going to school today blues.‚Äù Dr. appointment? No worries. You can do your work from home for that day.

I‚Äôll admit I was worried. As I‚Äôm becoming more comfortable with technology I have one concern...I may break out in song forgetting that adults can hear me too. üôÇ. I also am an artist that is only appreciated by 5 year olds. üôÇ.

shared_text:
New Style Church is feeling happy.
August 17 at 4:02 PM ¬∑

We had a great time feeding over 100 teachers, administrators, bus drivers and staff in the Coosa County School System with lunch today. As always, many thanks to our volunteers for coming out to help us serve. Special thanks to Superintendent Andi Wilson for allowing us this opportunity to serve. Lastly, we are grateful to our generous sponsor J.R.‚Äôs for partnering with our church for this community outreach event. #communityservice #back2school #coosacountyschools #wearenewstylechurch #Christcentered #Communitydriven

You will need to report to the back of the school and bring your completed paperwork at the following times:

If the last name of one or both parents begins with A-C, please arrive at 8:00 a.m.
If the last name of one or both parents begins with D-G, please arrive at 9:00 a.m.
If the last name of one or both parents begins with H-J. please arrive at 10:00 a.m.
If the last name of one or both parents begins with K-M, please arrive at 12:00 p.m.
If the last name of one or both parents begins with N-S, please arrive at 1:00 p.m.
If the last name of one or both parents begins with T-Z, please arrive at 2:00 p.m.

Thank you and Go Cougars!

for your support and Pastor Matthew Reams/Central Baptist Association for your willingness to support as well.

shared_text:
AHSAA Radio Network
July 22 at 2:30 PM ¬∑

#WednesdayCoachSpotlight presented by Thompson Tractor: Joe Belyeu spent all of his coaching career around the Coosa area. He coached his first 5 seasons at Goodwater High School winning 3 area championships and advancing to the Elite 8 in his first season in 1984 and reaching the Final 4 in 1987. He then moved to Central High School Coosa County for the 1988-1989 season and spent the next 26 years there winning 16 Area Championships, advancing to 4 Elite Eights, 5 final fours and winning the State Championship 4 times. He finished his career after the 2013-2014 season with more than 580 career victories.

post_text: Thanks to all parents and guardians who attended the general orientation session last night. If you did not attend, please contact your school to get an appointment for picking up an enrollment package.
text: Thanks to all parents and guardians who attended the general orientation session last night. If you did not attend, please contact your school to get an appointment for picking up an enrollment package.

shared_text:
Central Coosa Elementary PTO
July 16 at 4:51 PM ¬∑

There were many comments about having trouble hearing the FB Live, here is a quick recap:

This is the current plan- subject to change with guidance from the State Dept. and CDC.
Communication is KEY between parents and the school. Please work with us to make sure we can work together and make this year a great success.

Elementary Options:
Virtual Option- Your child will be enrolled in the Coosa County School System, but will not physically attend school at all. Your child will receive a chromebook. They will participate in a program aligned with the same academic standards that are taught in the schools. You must have strong and reliable internet service OR have a plan in place for your child to be able to complete their assignments daily (drive to a place with wifi, go to a friend/family member‚Äôs house with wifi). There will be a local teacher assigned to monitor your child‚Äôs progress, but parents must ensure students are completing their assignments to the best of their ability, meeting deadlines, etc. so that they are on track to master all required skills for their grade level. ** NOTE- You must commit to your choice for at least one nine weeks. If after the first quarter, you decide that Virtual was not the best choice for your family, they can switch to in-person, but they cannot do this in the middle of the nine weeks.
In-Person- Your child will attend school daily, as they did before the pandemic, with additional safety and sanitizing procedures in place. Classes will be manageable sizes (18-20) and students will be distanced/separated as much as possible.

High School Options:
Virtual Option- Same as above.
Hybrid- Some days during the week, your child will be at school, some days they will be working from home. This doesn‚Äôt require you to have internet at home. Before students leave school, they will download the assignments/materials they need onto their chromebook for the day they will be working at home so they have everything they need. Students will be required to ‚Äúcall in‚Äù to virtually attend class via a Google Meet- It can be a call in (from a phone) or video conference via chromebook if you have internet conference. Students will have to call in/log in to each class- this will count as their attendance and participation. The following day, the student will attend school and will have the opportunity to get information clarified, work with the teacher in person, etc. Your child may be attending Monday/Wednesday or Tuesday/Thursday with Friday being a mix of students. (This will be discussed further at orientation). Many students will be participating in dual enrollment and this option makes this more feasible as well!

The Alert Level will be closely monitored.
We must remember the close contact rule: If you must be in contact with others in less than a 6 ft radius, spend no more than 15 minutes in the closer proximity. We are going to be very intentional about keeping times that we must be in closer proximity to a minimal amount of time.

Face Shields/Masks:
All School Employees will be wearing a face shield or a face mask while on duty.
All of our students will be provided with face shields, which are a great alternative to face masks. (We have many asthmatic students). Face Shields will stay at school and will be cleaned each day.
There will be times that students will be asked to wear a face mask (for example, on the bus). We ask that parents supply masks for their students. Cloth masks are great because they can be washed and reused. It‚Äôs recommended you get several so one is available while the other is getting laundered. If your child doesn‚Äôt have a mask for some reason, we will provide one for them.
Some children with medical reasons may be assigned a different face shield to wear on the bus. We will be working with the parents and nurses to determine those students.

Water bottles:
We are asking that all parents provide plastic water bottles for their children, clearly labeled with their names.
These will be taken home daily, need to be washed and brought back to school.
Water fountains will not be available to drink out of, only to be used with supervision to refill water bottles. Elementary classrooms have water fountains in their classrooms for this purpose.

Restrooms:
There will be assigned times for restroom breaks as a class to help maintain social distancing procedures. Procedures will be in place for this.

Lockers:
High school students will not use hallway lockers this year, so they will be allowed to bring their backpacks to class with all their materials. There will be an assigned place in each classroom where backpacks will be stored during class time.
This doesn‚Äôt affect elementary students who will continue to use their lockers/cubbies in the classroom.

Chromebooks:
Each student will receive a chromebook, a charger, and a carrying case/bag. These should be kept together at all times.
These will travel back and forth from home to school daily. In the event that we had to shut down again, students will have what they need at home for instructional purposes.
Parents will be given these at parent orientation.
Chromebooks need to be charged nightly and brought back to school because they will be utilized in the classroom during the school day as well.
Teachers will teach lower elementary students how to use it.
Any damage to chromebooks will follow the same policy as before.

Library Books:
Physical books will not be checked out.
Students will have access to e-books using their chromebooks.

Parents, please work closely with us to help eliminate misbehaviors, discipline and dress code issues. We truly don‚Äôt have time for this with the current pandemic situation.
Bus misbehaviors truly cannot be tolerated as this is more than just the normal bus safety at stake- it‚Äôs the health of your child and other children as well. We need your support in talking with your children about appropriate behavior.

PE:
We will still have PE classes, Kindergarten - 9th grade (required by the state department). Outside time will be utilized as much as possible.
Talk with your child about social distancing. They will be able to play and will have times in which they are in close proximity with each other, but they can still be as safe as possible.

Buses:
If you feel more comfortable bringing your child to school versus riding the bus, please feel free to do so! That is always an option.
Loading and unloading buses will be a little different than in the past to limit the large gathering of students.

Temperature Checks:
Students will have their temperature checked when they get on the bus in the morning. We will be teaching students how to take their temperatures on their own.
Parents, please have a plan in place in case your child has a temperature of 100 degrees or more.
Please do not send your child to school if they have a temperature!

Visitors:
Limit visitations to the school unless it‚Äôs an absolute necessity.
Each school will have additional procedures in place for visitors for additional activities/events.

NEXT TUESDAY, July 21st @ 7 pm Keith Bullard Stadium:
Orientation for Parents only (no students).
Parents must wear masks. We will be social distancing in the stadium.
Will be going over several things such as guidelines. Most importantly, will be discussing modes of instruction so that you can make the best choice for your student.
Will be given an enrollment packet.

DROP OFF SUPPLY MEETING, July 28th behind the school in the big loop for 1st grade-12th grade. *See recent post for times and more info!*
Students will be divided up by last name
There will be several stations for you to stop in your car to pick something up or drop something off.
Most important thing to drop off will be your enrollment packet. We need every document that you receive at parent orientation completed by the 28th and dropped off.
You‚Äôll be picking up your child‚Äôs chromebook and dropping off school supplies at that time (we are trying to limit the people coming into the school).

‚ÄúMeet your teacher‚Äù will be held virtually via google meet.
Each teacher will be sending parents an invitation.

Kindergarten Orientation will be July 30th at 7 pm @ Keith Bullard Stadium.
Separate because these are brand new students.
Will have a separate drive thru and drop off scheduled later.

We will still be starting the school day at the same time. Additional info about this will be given at orientation.

We have several procedures in place to keep the schools clean and sanitized at the classroom and school level, daily and long term.

It sounds silly, but we will be keeping the school day as ‚Äúnormal‚Äù as possible‚Ä¶ as normal as our days are now.

Please read other comments and questions posted on various posts on the Coosa County School System page and the PTO page. Many questions have been asked and answered!

NEXT TUESDAY, July 21st @ 7 pm Keith Bullard Stadium:
Orientation for Parents only (no students).
Parents must wear masks. We will be social distancing in the stadium.
Will be going over several things such as guidelines. Most importantly, will be discussing modes of instruction so that you can make the best choice for your student.
Will be given an enrollment packet.

DROP OFF SUPPLY MEETING, July 28th behind the school in the big loop for 1st grade-12th grade. *See recent post for times and more info!*
Students will be divided up by last name
There will be several stations for you to stop in your car to pick something up or drop something off.
Most important thing to drop off will be your enrollment packet. We need every document that you receive at parent orientation completed by the 28th and dropped off.
You‚Äôll be picking up your child‚Äôs chromebook and dropping off school supplies at that time (we are trying to limit the people coming into the school).

‚ÄúMeet your teacher‚Äù will be held virtually via google meet.
Each teacher will be sending parents an invitation.

Kindergarten Orientation will be July 30th at 7 pm @ Keith Bullard Stadium.
Separate because these are brand new students.
Will have a separate drive thru and drop off scheduled later.

We will still be starting the school day at the same time. Additional info about this will be given at orientation.

We have several procedures in place to keep the schools clean and sanitized at the classroom and school level, daily and long term.

It sounds silly, but we will be keeping the school day as ‚Äúnormal‚Äù as possible‚Ä¶ as normal as our days are now.

Please read other comments and questions posted on various posts on the Coosa County School System page and the PTO page. Many questions have been asked and answered!

post_text:
There were many comments about having trouble hearing the FB Live, here is a quick recap:

This is the current plan- subject to change with guidance from the State Dept. and CDC.
Communication is KEY between parents and the school. Please work with us to make sure we can work together and make this year a great success.

Elementary Options:
Virtual Option- Your child will be enrolled in the Coosa County School System, but will not physically attend school at all. Your child will receive a chromebook. They will participate in a program aligned with the same academic standards that are taught in the schools. You must have strong and reliable internet service OR have a plan in place for your child to be able to complete their assignments daily (drive to a place with wifi, go to a friend/family member‚Äôs house with wifi). There will be a local teacher assigned to monitor your child‚Äôs progress, but parents must ensure students are completing their assignments to the best of their ability, meeting deadlines, etc. so that they are on track to master all required skills for their grade level. ** NOTE- You must commit to your choice for at least one nine weeks. If after the first quarter, you decide that Virtual was not the best choice for your family, they can switch to in-person, but they cannot do this in the middle of the nine weeks.
In-Person- Your child will attend school daily, as they did before the pandemic, with additional safety and sanitizing procedures in place. Classes will be manageable sizes (18-20) and students will be distanced/separated as much as possible.

High School Options:
Virtual Option- Same as above.
Hybrid- Some days during the week, your child will be at school, some days they will be working from home. This doesn‚Äôt require you to have internet at home. Before students leave school, they will download the assignments/materials they need onto their chromebook for the day they will be working at home so they have everything they need. Students will be required to ‚Äúcall in‚Äù to virtually attend class via a Google Meet- It can be a call in (from a phone) or video conference via chromebook if you have internet conference. Students will have to call in/log in to each class- this will count as their attendance and participation. The following day, the student will attend school and will have the opportunity to get information clarified, work with the teacher in person, etc. Your child may be attending Monday/Wednesday or Tuesday/Thursday with Friday being a mix of students. (This will be discussed further at orientation). Many students will be participating in dual enrollment and this option makes this more feasible as well!

The Alert Level will be closely monitored.
We must remember the close contact rule: If you must be in contact with others in less than a 6 ft radius, spend no more than 15 minutes in the closer proximity. We are going to be very intentional about keeping times that we must be in closer proximity to a minimal amount of time.

Face Shields/Masks:
All School Employees will be wearing a face shield or a face mask while on duty.
All of our students will be provided with face shields, which are a great alternative to face masks. (We have many asthmatic students). Face Shields will stay at school and will be cleaned each day.
There will be times that students will be asked to wear a face mask (for example, on the bus). We ask that parents supply masks for their students. Cloth masks are great because they can be washed and reused. It‚Äôs recommended you get several so one is available while the other is getting laundered. If your child doesn‚Äôt have a mask for some reason, we will provide one for them.
Some children with medical reasons may be assigned a different face shield to wear on the bus. We will be working with the parents and nurses to determine those students.

Water bottles:
We are asking that all parents provide plastic water bottles for their children, clearly labeled with their names.
These will be taken home daily, need to be washed and brought back to school.
Water fountains will not be available to drink out of, only to be used with supervision to refill water bottles. Elementary classrooms have water fountains in their classrooms for this purpose.

Restrooms:
There will be assigned times for restroom breaks as a class to help maintain social distancing procedures. Procedures will be in place for this.

Lockers:
High school students will not use hallway lockers this year, so they will be allowed to bring their backpacks to class with all their materials. There will be an assigned place in each classroom where backpacks will be stored during class time.
This doesn‚Äôt affect elementary students who will continue to use their lockers/cubbies in the classroom.

Chromebooks:
Each student will receive a chromebook, a charger, and a carrying case/bag. These should be kept together at all times.
These will travel back and forth from home to school daily. In the event that we had to shut down again, students will have what they need at home for instructional purposes.
Parents will be given these at parent orientation.
Chromebooks need to be charged nightly and brought back to school because they will be utilized in the classroom during the school day as well.
Teachers will teach lower elementary students how to use it.
Any damage to chromebooks will follow the same policy as before.

Library Books:
Physical books will not be checked out.
Students will have access to e-books using their chromebooks.

Parents, please work closely with us to help eliminate misbehaviors, discipline and dress code issues. We truly don‚Äôt have time for this with the current pandemic situation.
Bus misbehaviors truly cannot be tolerated as this is more than just the normal bus safety at stake- it‚Äôs the health of your child and other children as well. We need your support in talking with your children about appropriate behavior.

PE:
We will still have PE classes, Kindergarten - 9th grade (required by the state department). Outside time will be utilized as much as possible.
Talk with your child about social distancing. They will be able to play and will have times in which they are in close proximity with each other, but they can still be as safe as possible.

Buses:
If you feel more comfortable bringing your child to school versus riding the bus, please feel free to do so! That is always an option.
Loading and unloading buses will be a little different than in the past to limit the large gathering of students.

Temperature Checks:
Students will have their temperature checked when they get on the bus in the morning. We will be teaching students how to take their temperatures on their own.
Parents, please have a plan in place in case your child has a temperature of 100 degrees or more.
Please do not send your child to school if they have a temperature!

Visitors:
Limit visitations to the school unless it‚Äôs an absolute necessity.
Each school will have additional procedures in place for visitors for additional activities/events.

NEXT TUESDAY, July 21st @ 7 pm Keith Bullard Stadium:
Orientation for Parents only (no students).
Parents must wear masks. We will be social distancing in the stadium.
Will be going over several things such as guidelines. Most importantly, will be discussing modes of instruction so that you can make the best choice for your student.
Will be given an enrollment packet.

DROP OFF SUPPLY MEETING, July 28th behind the school in the big loop for 1st grade-12th grade. *See recent post for times and more info!*
Students will be divided up by last name
There will be several stations for you to stop in your car to pick something up or drop something off.
Most important thing to drop off will be your enrollment packet. We need every document that you receive at parent orientation completed by the 28th and dropped off.
You‚Äôll be picking up your child‚Äôs chromebook and dropping off school supplies at that time (we are trying to limit the people coming into the school).

‚ÄúMeet your teacher‚Äù will be held virtually via google meet.
Each teacher will be sending parents an invitation.

Kindergarten Orientation will be July 30th at 7 pm @ Keith Bullard Stadium.
Separate because these are brand new students.
Will have a separate drive thru and drop off scheduled later.

We will still be starting the school day at the same time. Additional info about this will be given at orientation.

We have several procedures in place to keep the schools clean and sanitized at the classroom and school level, daily and long term.

It sounds silly, but we will be keeping the school day as ‚Äúnormal‚Äù as possible‚Ä¶ as normal as our days are now.

Please read other comments and questions posted on various posts on the Coosa County School System page and the PTO page. Many questions have been asked and answered!

post_text:
Information shared by pediatricians in the Birmingham area regarding the need for students to attend school physically and safely and how it can be done.
Re: Best Practices regarding Re-Opening Schools

To Whom it May Concern,

We, the undersigned, are physician parents who work and live in the greater Birmingham area. We appreciate the countless hours you have spent responding to the COVID19 pandemic. As physicians serving on the frontlines with a vested interest in our patients and children, we wish to endorse the below evidence-based guidelines to re-open Alabama schools. As a group we agree with the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) that the goal of re-opening schools should focus on children returning to school physically and safely. While there are data showing children are less likely to spread COVID19 and less likely to have severe disease compared to adults, this is still a very serious illness. Among the 983 COVID deaths in Alabama to date, two have been children. We believe that schools can and should re-open in a meaningful and sustainable way. However, this is a novel virus and will require a novel response to control the spread in schools. These are our medical recommendations to aid in our common goal of safe schools for this upcoming school year:

¬∑ Face coverings must be mandated when indoors. These include medical masks, reusable fabric masks, gaiters or clear face shields. With very few medical exceptions, children over 2 can be taught to wear these for extended periods of time. Universal masking is crucial to controlling spread of COVID19 because the wearers‚Äô mask protects others. If only a few wear them, they are not effective. A mandate is the best way to ensure universal face coverings. Parents will need time and resources to teach their children how to wear face coverings. Just like riding a bike or any other skill, children must be taught and encouraged to maintain their skills. We can partner with schools to develop tools for education, but the mandate needs to be step one. From a medical standpoint, face coverings are the best chance schools have to re-open and stay open.1
¬∑ Access to soap, water and paper towels with frequent hand-washing breaks coupled with sanitizer stations throughout the school will help decrease spread. Sanitizing spray and paper towels to wipe down frequently touched surfaces is an alternative to sanitizing wipes that are in short supply.1
¬∑ Educate parents on the critical importance of keeping children home when ill. While activities like daily on-site temperature screening make us feel safer, these screenings have not been shown to reduce risk of spread in a meaningful way. We have also found that some families will answer ‚Äúno‚Äù when being screened for illness or exposure only to reveal a significant history of illness or exposure later in the visit. This observation does not mean these processes should not be used, but they are limited in efficacy and must be used in combination with other safe guards.
¬∑ Temperature screening must balance the practicality and resources of performing these screening procedures for large numbers of students and staff with the information known about how children manifest COVID-19 infection, the risk of transmission in schools, and the possible lost instructional time to conduct the screenings.‚Äù1
¬∑ Use all available outdoor spaces in creative ways to give kids more time outside. Gathering outdoors is inherently safer during a pandemic. Outdoor time will also give kids breaks from face coverings. Thinking creatively about outdoor spaces for lunch and snacks would enable more typical socialization while eating. Opening windows in classrooms and other spaces would also improve ventilation and reduce risk.1
¬∑ Offer varying hybrids of in person attendance and eLearning. Parents should be given flexibility to change at certain intervals (nine weeks or semester) to account for changing needs and special conditions such as family work constraints or illness. While we want all children to have an option to be in school, reduction in volume of students in the school on a daily basis will inherently make controlling and containing viral spread easier. 1,2
¬∑ Develop a COVID prevention plan for all school activities and modify or eliminate high-risk activities. Some of the high risk activities include assemblies, indoor singing, indoor use of wind instruments, spectators at sporting events, crowded locker rooms, parental visits. Some activities that are high risk are also necessary like eating lunch or snacks and pick-up/drop-off. Those activities will need staggered schedules, scrutiny, and creative planning to reduce risks.
¬∑ Develop and communicate a clear plan for classroom or school wide outbreaks. COVID outbreaks will be a part of the 2020-2021 school year. Local pediatricians are already seeing similar outbreaks in daycares, summer sports leagues, and camps. Because COVID19 symptoms can be very mild and often do not involve a fever in children, diagnosis and containment of outbreaks is especially complex. Adding to the difficulty of this task is the fact that our best test available has a 20-30% false negative rate.3
¬∑ Face Coverings will reduce the need for quarantine. We know that people infected with COVID19 can spread the virus for up to 14 days, with or without symptoms. The current recommendation by the Jefferson County Department of Public Health is that students return to school 14 days after a positive test was collected or 14 days from symptom start as long as symptom free for 3 days without any medications such as Tylenol or Motrin. If a student or staff has a close contact with someone who is infected (more than 15 min, less than 6 feet, indoors without a face covering), they will meet criteria for a 14 day quarantine. If that same interaction involved face coverings for both parties involved, the interaction is no longer considered a close contact.
¬∑ Flu vaccines will be especially important this season. We hope all schools will encourage students to vaccinate against influenza this season. We do not currently know what co-infection with influenza and COVID19 will look like. We hope families will reduce the risk of infection by choosing to vaccinate.

1.American Academy of Pediatrics COVID-19 Planning Considerations: Guidance for School Re-entry. https://services.aap.org/en/pages/2019-novel-coronavirus-covid-19-infections/clinical-guidance/covid-19-planning-considerations-return-to-in-person-education-in-schools/
2. Cooks Children‚Äôs Hospital Recommendations for the Practical, Fair, and Safe Reopening of Public Schools K-12 in the State of Texas. https://cookchildrens.org/coronavirus/action/Pages/Safe-Reopening.aspx
3. Ai Tang Xiao, Yi Xin Tong, Chun Gao, Li Zhu, Yu Jie Zhang, Sheng Zhang,Dynamic profile of RT-PCR findings from 301 COVID-19 patients in Wuhan, China: A descriptive study, Journal of Clinical Virology, Volume 127, 2020, 104346, ISSN 1386-6532

In closing, we wish to serve as a resource and want to work together to reach our common goal of ensuring a safe and sustainable return to school. We are especially passionate about this process as we will be the ones taking care of patients and families affected by COVID19. We are on the front lines of fighting this horrifying pandemic and see, firsthand, the fear, the pain and the devastation families experience. We greatly appreciate your consideration of our input. Please reach out to us for any further needs, including additional references.

Sincerely,

Gigi Youngblood, MD
Pediatrician
Shades Cahaba Elementary Parent
garlandgail@yahoo.com

Ellen Eaton, MD, MSPH
Infectious Diseases
Shades Cahaba Elementary Parent

shared_text:
COOKCHILDRENS.ORG
Recommendations for the Practical, Fair, and Safe Reopening of Public Schools K-12 in the State of Texas
text:
Information shared by pediatricians in the Birmingham area regarding the need for students to attend school physically and safely and how it can be done.
Re: Best Practices regarding Re-Opening Schools

To Whom it May Concern,

We, the undersigned, are physician parents who work and live in the greater Birmingham area. We appreciate the countless hours you have spent responding to the COVID19 pandemic. As physicians serving on the frontlines with a vested interest in our patients and children, we wish to endorse the below evidence-based guidelines to re-open Alabama schools. As a group we agree with the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) that the goal of re-opening schools should focus on children returning to school physically and safely. While there are data showing children are less likely to spread COVID19 and less likely to have severe disease compared to adults, this is still a very serious illness. Among the 983 COVID deaths in Alabama to date, two have been children. We believe that schools can and should re-open in a meaningful and sustainable way. However, this is a novel virus and will require a novel response to control the spread in schools. These are our medical recommendations to aid in our common goal of safe schools for this upcoming school year:

¬∑ Face coverings must be mandated when indoors. These include medical masks, reusable fabric masks, gaiters or clear face shields. With very few medical exceptions, children over 2 can be taught to wear these for extended periods of time. Universal masking is crucial to controlling spread of COVID19 because the wearers‚Äô mask protects others. If only a few wear them, they are not effective. A mandate is the best way to ensure universal face coverings. Parents will need time and resources to teach their children how to wear face coverings. Just like riding a bike or any other skill, children must be taught and encouraged to maintain their skills. We can partner with schools to develop tools for education, but the mandate needs to be step one. From a medical standpoint, face coverings are the best chance schools have to re-open and stay open.1
¬∑ Access to soap, water and paper towels with frequent hand-washing breaks coupled with sanitizer stations throughout the school will help decrease spread. Sanitizing spray and paper towels to wipe down frequently touched surfaces is an alternative to sanitizing wipes that are in short supply.1
¬∑ Educate parents on the critical importance of keeping children home when ill. While activities like daily on-site temperature screening make us feel safer, these screenings have not been shown to reduce risk of spread in a meaningful way. We have also found that some families will answer ‚Äúno‚Äù when being screened for illness or exposure only to reveal a significant history of illness or exposure later in the visit. This observation does not mean these processes should not be used, but they are limited in efficacy and must be used in combination with other safe guards.
¬∑ Temperature screening must balance the practicality and resources of performing these screening procedures for large numbers of students and staff with the information known about how children manifest COVID-19 infection, the risk of transmission in schools, and the possible lost instructional time to conduct the screenings.‚Äù1
¬∑ Use all available outdoor spaces in creative ways to give kids more time outside. Gathering outdoors is inherently safer during a pandemic. Outdoor time will also give kids breaks from face coverings. Thinking creatively about outdoor spaces for lunch and snacks would enable more typical socialization while eating. Opening windows in classrooms and other spaces would also improve ventilation and reduce risk.1
¬∑ Offer varying hybrids of in person attendance and eLearning. Parents should be given flexibility to change at certain intervals (nine weeks or semester) to account for changing needs and special conditions such as family work constraints or illness. While we want all children to have an option to be in school, reduction in volume of students in the school on a daily basis will inherently make controlling and containing viral spread easier. 1,2
¬∑ Develop a COVID prevention plan for all school activities and modify or eliminate high-risk activities. Some of the high risk activities include assemblies, indoor singing, indoor use of wind instruments, spectators at sporting events, crowded locker rooms, parental visits. Some activities that are high risk are also necessary like eating lunch or snacks and pick-up/drop-off. Those activities will need staggered schedules, scrutiny, and creative planning to reduce risks.
¬∑ Develop and communicate a clear plan for classroom or school wide outbreaks. COVID outbreaks will be a part of the 2020-2021 school year. Local pediatricians are already seeing similar outbreaks in daycares, summer sports leagues, and camps. Because COVID19 symptoms can be very mild and often do not involve a fever in children, diagnosis and containment of outbreaks is especially complex. Adding to the difficulty of this task is the fact that our best test available has a 20-30% false negative rate.3
¬∑ Face Coverings will reduce the need for quarantine. We know that people infected with COVID19 can spread the virus for up to 14 days, with or without symptoms. The current recommendation by the Jefferson County Department of Public Health is that students return to school 14 days after a positive test was collected or 14 days from symptom start as long as symptom free for 3 days without any medications such as Tylenol or Motrin. If a student or staff has a close contact with someone who is infected (more than 15 min, less than 6 feet, indoors without a face covering), they will meet criteria for a 14 day quarantine. If that same interaction involved face coverings for both parties involved, the interaction is no longer considered a close contact.
¬∑ Flu vaccines will be especially important this season. We hope all schools will encourage students to vaccinate against influenza this season. We do not currently know what co-infection with influenza and COVID19 will look like. We hope families will reduce the risk of infection by choosing to vaccinate.

1.American Academy of Pediatrics COVID-19 Planning Considerations: Guidance for School Re-entry. https://services.aap.org/en/pages/2019-novel-coronavirus-covid-19-infections/clinical-guidance/covid-19-planning-considerations-return-to-in-person-education-in-schools/
2. Cooks Children‚Äôs Hospital Recommendations for the Practical, Fair, and Safe Reopening of Public Schools K-12 in the State of Texas. https://cookchildrens.org/coronavirus/action/Pages/Safe-Reopening.aspx
3. Ai Tang Xiao, Yi Xin Tong, Chun Gao, Li Zhu, Yu Jie Zhang, Sheng Zhang,Dynamic profile of RT-PCR findings from 301 COVID-19 patients in Wuhan, China: A descriptive study, Journal of Clinical Virology, Volume 127, 2020, 104346, ISSN 1386-6532

In closing, we wish to serve as a resource and want to work together to reach our common goal of ensuring a safe and sustainable return to school. We are especially passionate about this process as we will be the ones taking care of patients and families affected by COVID19. We are on the front lines of fighting this horrifying pandemic and see, firsthand, the fear, the pain and the devastation families experience. We greatly appreciate your consideration of our input. Please reach out to us for any further needs, including additional references.

Sincerely,

Gigi Youngblood, MD
Pediatrician
Shades Cahaba Elementary Parent
garlandgail@yahoo.com

Ellen Eaton, MD, MSPH
Infectious Diseases
Shades Cahaba Elementary Parent
eeaton@uabmc.edu

City of Goodwater 17.3 to 31.7

The City of Goodwater has info on all their water bills and askes people who come to pay their bills if they can help them complete their census and they do it right then.

The school system called all of last years parents and helped them complete their census.

What is your district or city doing?

June 13 at 7:44 PM ¬∑

Thank you so much to the Coosa County School System for doing their part for our great county!!!!
Andi F. Wilson, Superintendent says...The school system Wednesday, June 17th, Coosa County teachers will participate in a Census Blitz by reaching out to all students and their contacts in order to assist in getting Coosa County residents signed up for the Census. The teachers in Coosa County are willing to do ALL they can to improve the Census participation rate for Coosa County. SGA students are also reaching out to family members and signing up at least 10 family members. The school system is happy to do our part in Census work.

post_text: This past Thursday I heard the news of Coosa County DHR worker, Whitney Bradley, passing away unexpectedly. Whitney worked closely with the school system as she supported families we both shared. She was one of a kind and will be greatly missed as a link families needed in order to get on track. Thank you for your service, Whitney. You were a blessing in MANY ways. Let's all remember her family as they lay her to rest tomorrow in Valley, Alabama.

post_text:
From Coach Thomas regarding CHS football:

Because of the COVID-19 pandemic, summer workouts will change for football. Only twelve student athletes may work out at a time. Therefore, a roster has been sent to all students via email. You must add your name to the roster in order to participate in workouts. There will be two workout groups. This is subject to change according to the number of participants. Parents, you must drop your child off at the main ticket booth at the stadium and wait for your child‚Äôs temperature to be taken. All students will wear masks when necessary(If your child does not have one, the school will provide it). Athletes driving will park in the student parking lot. Workouts will begin June 8th according to the following schedule:

Monday-Thursday

Group 1 Group 2

9:00-11:00 11:00-1:00

post_text: Look what upcoming SENIOR, JR CHAPMAN has accomplished!!! He submitted a proficiency application based on his work experience in his father's forestry business. JR was named the 1st place Individual across the state of Alabama and is bringing home a state championship to Coosa County! This is an enormous success that very few students experience! In addition, JR will go on to represent Coosa County FFA and the Alabama FFA Association in the Forest Management & Products Proficiency Area at the National FFA Convention in October. So proud of this special young man!!!

post_text: Let's make this event special. See the Ceremony Guide for this once-in -a-lifetime event!
shared_text:
Coosa County School System
May 13 at 5:33 PM ¬∑

High School Graduation Ceremony Guide

Dress the part for a once-in-a-lifetime event that's rich in style and traditions.

Ceremony Basics

There's no greater recognition of a graduate's achievements than a high school graduation ceremony, or commencement. Diplomas are "conferred" or handed out to graduating seniors and the speakers selected for this event often include community dignitaries, alumni and students. The valedictorian, the highest-ranking academic student in the graduation class, usually speaks.

Many schools have to restrict attendance for space reasons. Make sure to check with your school to see if there will be limitations on the number of people you can invite to the ceremony. If your school has space restrictions and you're facing a dilemma about who to include, try these tips:

Talk to your friends and family members and explain that while you want them at graduation, each graduate is allowed only a limited number of guests. Most people will understand and even possibly volunteer to give up their ticket so that someone else may attend.
Consider inviting only one grandparent or aunt or uncle from each wing of your family.
Come up with a creative solution that will feel fair to everyone, such as drawing names.
Let everyone who is not able to attend know they will be invited to the graduation party. Make sure to share your photos and videos to make them feel included.

Ceremony Etiquette

What are the traditions of your particular school? If graduation is a more formal and somber right of passage, it's probably better to replace whooping and hollering with applause.
In most schools, the handing out of diplomas is a quick and orderly process. Make sure that when you show pride in your graduate, you aren't drowning out the recognition of another.
Life's milestones deserve everyone's full attention. Turn off your cell phones and resist the urge to text until the entire ceremony is over. Remain in your seat until the last students receive their diplomas so that they feel properly acknowledged.

The Cap and Gown

Preparing to march to "Pomp and Circumstance" requires wearing the traditional graduation cap and gown, a tradition that dates back centuries to the early universities in Europe.

Here's how to wear your cap and gown

The graduation cap is worn flat on the head, parallel to the floor. The front point of the cap should be centered on the forehead.
The graduation gown should fall midway between the knee and ankle.
Men should remove their graduation caps during the school song and the National Anthem.
Tassels are usually worn on the right side and shifted to the left when graduates receive their diplomas.
Men generally wear dark trousers and dress shirts and ties under their graduation gowns.
Women generally wear lightweight dresses or blouses and skirts that do not hang below their graduation gowns. They can also wear a detachable white collar that adds a more finished, decorative touch.
Flowers and jewelry should not be worn on the academic gown.
Caps and gowns can be accessorized with specific regalia like stoles and honor cords in keeping with the traditions of the school.

The Coosa County News
April 14 at 9:59 AM ¬∑

Per David Stover:

Thank you for supporting the Cougar Cafe (baseball concession) when we were open the first week of April. Thanks to your purchases and donations we were able to raise the money to purchase the shadow boxes we traditionally give our seniors. The Central Cougar baseball program would have been celebrating our Senior Night tonight; hence we would like to recognize our seniors by name. Once conditions permit, we will hold our Senior Night ceremony and present our seniors with their shadow boxes.

Baseball Players:

1. Daniel, Donta
2. Duncan, Dawson
3. Meadows, Landon
4. Murchison, Bryer
5. Payne, Ryan

Diamond Dolls:

1. Brekle, Journey
2. Calhoun, Deliah
3. Gibbs, Edlena
4. Graham, Breanna
5. Harrell, Arianna
6. Kelly, Jania
7. Milam, Savanna
8. Moon, MonTia
9. Sims, Brooklin
10. Thornton, Remy

post_text:
The school system heard the news the same time the rest of Alabama did. We have a webinar in the morning with Dr. Mackey which I feel will be lengthy, but full of next step information. I've seen posts that reflect things not happening for the remainder of the year. I want to clarify information. If you have questions, I will not be able to answer them until after our webinar and meeting with our administrators. Do not be upset if you do not get an answer right away. I hope to do a FB LIVE post tomorrow afternoon or evening. Remember, we are on SPRING BREAK THIS WEEK. LAST WEEK WAS LIKE ABSENCES DUE TO A SEVERE SITUATION (like snow or ice storm). We have not missed too much instruction so the goal will be getting things in place to complete coursework per student. I appreciate your patience as we ALL are experiencing something VERY NEW. Together we CAN make this happen for all!!

JUST TO CLARIFY.....
The school building will be closed to students for the remainder of the year.
Instruction will continue so all can complete coursework.
Graduation will occur for seniors, ESPECIALLY. The time will be determined at a later date.
PREVENTING LOSS OF LEARNING IS IMPORTANT FOR OUR STUDENTS.

Please SHARE, SHARE,SHARE!

Thank you to all donors and county partners who made this possible!

post_text: https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=2555301844707352&id=1804658893104988
shared_text:
Science Mom
March 15 at 1:15 AM ¬∑

School has been canceled in more than a dozen states, many of them with very short notice. If you're worried about your child falling behind with their learning or wasting away in front of netflix next week- we're here to help! Join us on Monday, March 16th, for a daily show featuring science and math lessons, crafts and games. Hosted by Science Mom and Math Dad, this two hour livestream is a wonderful way to put some fun learning into your quarantine.

Each show will feature a science lesson, math activities, interactive games, and stories. If you'd like to share your creation with other families who are following along with Quarantime, post it to Instagram with the hashtags #quarantime and #sciencemomsquad. Feel free to tag me too! We can't wait to see what you come up with!

At the end of each show, we'll take several minutes to answer YOUR questions. If you'd like to submit a question in advance, email us at questions@science.mom. Please note that we get more questions submitted than we have time to answer -we still love to hear from you even if you aren't able to reply!

You can watch the Livestream here on the Science Mom Facebook page (click on the "videos" tab) or by going to www.youtube.com/sciencemom A replay is available afterward on both Facebook the Science Mom YouTube channel.

While our science and math lessons are aimed at kids age 7-12, this is a family-friendly show that is for BOTH kids and parents (and any elderly people who are feeling isolated at home and would like to watch some science and math lessons and participate in a few crafts).

Each day we post a simple worksheet that goes along with the show. You can find those at www.patreon.com/sciencemom.

This information was released by the SDE this morning. Keeping you updated on the latest.

We will continue to work through this together to support ‚ÄúEvery Child, Every Chance, Every Day.‚Äù

If you are a parent and have a COVID-19 related question, click COVID19PARENTS@ALSDE.EDU.

If you are a school employee and have a COVID-19 related question, click COVID19SCHOOLS@ALSDE.EDU.

ALSDE.EDU
Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) Education Information

post_text: Look for information regarding food delivery soon. The school system will not be cooking meals but we will be meeting with a group tomorrow regarding alternate plans. Just want to keep everyone updated with the latest information.
text: Look for information regarding food delivery soon. The school system will not be cooking meals but we will be meeting with a group tomorrow regarding alternate plans. Just want to keep everyone updated with the latest information.

post_text: The new information we received from the SDE was that the CDC has changed the gathering limits from 500 to 50. We are asking that employees do not attend the school. If we have the germs, they will die after ten days. Teachers will be contacting parents and/or students regarding remedial work possibilities. If your child receives medications at school, the school nurse will be contacting you today to pick up medications. Again, this is a minute by minute situation. We are all in unchartered territory. We appreciate your patience and cooperation.

We appreciate your patience and cooperation.

post_text:
So this happened today. What if it happened EVERY DAY!!!
https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=10158085740447065&id=768367064
shared_text:
Hannah Collins is with Deanna Strickland and 5 others.
February 22 at 3:08 AM ¬∑

IEP Meetings get a bad rap... But y‚Äôall, I had the sweetest meeting today and my heart is so full. I have to tell you about it. Getting to share accomplishments, strengths, and precious moments is my favorite part of these meetings. I love to tell parents about how their kids have progressed in communication, academic, or functional skills, but I absolutely ADORE getting to share about the friendships they are making, how they make us laugh and surprise us, and let them know how much they are loved! I think there were some ‚Äúhappy tears‚Äù shed and definitely some warm fuzzies felt by all ‚ô•Ô∏è

Our meeting was extra special though... This mama was SO complementary! Of me and the other teachers in my room, of the work we are doing with her son, of our school system and other members of our staff... she had so many nice things to say! With job and other life changes, her priority has been that he stays in here in Coosa County because she has never been so pleased. It was SO wonderful to hear! We NEED to hear it sometimes! We definitely don‚Äôt hear it enough.

You always hear about the negative things. Negativity spreads so easily; Let‚Äôs be conscious about sharing the positives too. üòä #spedlifeisthebestlife #imjusthereforthekids #coosacountyschools #centralcoosa

post_text: Please read and share!
shared_text:
Coosa County School System
February 20 at 8:49 PM ¬∑

A Note from the Superintendent of Education
‚ÄúRow, row, row our buses, all the way to school, the more it rains, the harder we row, each and every day!!‚Äù, in our best singing voice ever!!! When will this rain and threatening weather end? Thankfully, we have been blessed with safe travels all this week. From rain to ice, 70 weather to 20 degree weather within a few days. This reminds me of classroom management at times. Students can be so engaged in lessons or activities and all of a sudden an interruption occurs and the rest of the day could lend itself to chaos. The key is keeping the routine as close to normal as possible but sometimes that is easier said than done.
The students are receiving a long weekend with today and Monday off, while teachers are spending today in professional development. The main focus for learning reflects the Alabama Literacy Act and what is involved in the act. I mentioned last week that teachers are receiving job-embedded professional development, which means they learn while they practice implementation strategies with students in the classroom. This opportunity occurred again this week as the regional Alabama Reading Initiative Reading Coach came to Central Elementary to support the local reading coach and teachers with reading implementation. The support is a major part of the Act.
Today, teachers will be developing school wide literacy plans to optimize opportunities for reading and building reading proficiency. Although the Act is geared toward kindergarten through third grades, the overall focus of reading instruction continues through 12th grade. Even if teachers are not certified in the area of reading, because of its importance to all facets of life, in general, there should be a depth of reading instruction shared in all classrooms.

I have been participating in a comprehensive literacy study with other educators throughout the state and we are learning about factors that could be impeding the importance of reading in our schools. Most of the participants are in rural with high poverty. In conjunction with this study, I have also been reading a book called, Cultivating Genius. The author, Gholdy Muhammad, reminds us that literacy can be a source of power for young people and a key to transforming their lives. Reading is so much more than calling words but an avenue to learn to debate, express feelings, share cultures and so, so much more. If you have not been encouraging your children or grandchildren to read AND write, please begin that now. It is never too late.

Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

The author, Gholdy Muhammad, reminds us that literacy can be a source of power for young people and a key to transforming their lives. Reading is so much more than calling words but an avenue to learn to debate, express feelings, share cultures and so, so much more. If you have not been encouraging your children or grandchildren to read AND write, please begin that now. It is never too late.

Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶
text:
A Note from the Superintendent of Education
‚ÄúRow, row, row our buses, all the way to school, the more it rains, the harder we row, each and every day!!‚Äù, in our best singing voice ever!!! When will this rain and threatening weather end? Thankfully, we have been blessed with safe travels all this week. From rain to ice, 70 weather to 20 degree weather within a few days. This reminds me of classroom management at times. Students can be so engaged in lessons or activities and all of a sudden an interruption occurs and the rest of the day could lend itself to chaos. The key is keeping the routine as close to normal as possible but sometimes that is easier said than done.
The students are receiving a long weekend with today and Monday off, while teachers are spending today in professional development. The main focus for learning reflects the Alabama Literacy Act and what is involved in the act. I mentioned last week that teachers are receiving job-embedded professional development, which means they learn while they practice implementation strategies with students in the classroom. This opportunity occurred again this week as the regional Alabama Reading Initiative Reading Coach came to Central Elementary to support the local reading coach and teachers with reading implementation. The support is a major part of the Act.
Today, teachers will be developing school wide literacy plans to optimize opportunities for reading and building reading proficiency. Although the Act is geared toward kindergarten through third grades, the overall focus of reading instruction continues through 12th grade. Even if teachers are not certified in the area of reading, because of its importance to all facets of life, in general, there should be a depth of reading instruction shared in all classrooms.

I have been participating in a comprehensive literacy study with other educators throughout the state and we are learning about factors that could be impeding the importance of reading in our schools. Most of the participants are in rural with high poverty. In conjunction with this study, I have also been reading a book called, Cultivating Genius. The author, Gholdy Muhammad, reminds us that literacy can be a source of power for young people and a key to transforming their lives. Reading is so much more than calling words but an avenue to learn to debate, express feelings, share cultures and so, so much more. If you have not been encouraging your children or grandchildren to read AND write, please begin that now. It is never too late.

Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

post_text: Please read and share! Great things are happening in our schools!
shared_text:
Coosa County School System
February 20 at 8:47 PM ¬∑

A Note from the Superintendent of Education
The school system had a very exciting weekend, this past week with students participating in both math and robotics competitions. The outcomes were rewarding as several individual and group awards were claimed in the math competition. The first ever experience in state completion by the robotics team led to a 15th place out of 36 teams. Both competitions were great experiences for all students and sponsors alike. Not only were academic competitions held this weekend but athletic competitions in basketball are winding down to area competitions in the next few days. The senior players, boys and girls, were recognized Tuesday night during the Thorsby game. We are extra proud of these students for their continued commitment of participating in extracurricular activities during high school. It is not an easy task juggling academics and athletics, but these students were up for the challenge. We are so proud of our students and their accomplishments.
Next week will begin the legislative session in Montgomery with a number of topics already being discussed. This time last year, talks were beginning regarding the Alabama Literacy Act which proved to be one of the most talked about bills on the agenda. Today school systems across the state are working to ensure expectations of this act are being met. In order to address literacy for students, we must know what deficits students are showing. We are able to identify deficits based upon assessments that focus on the components of reading: phonemic awareness, phonics, vocabulary fluency and comprehension
With support from the Alabama Reading Initiative, ARI, the Central Elementary reading coach and 2nd grade teachers participated in job-embedded professional development this week to practice and build their craft of reading instruction. Implementation plans were created and will be monitored by administration in order to give as much support as possible to students and reading instruction. Additionally, the reading coach will work to support the same professional development opportunity for other reading teachers in grades K, 1st and 3rd. As a reminder, if students are not reading on third grade level by the end of third grade, they will not be promoted to the fourth grade.
This feat cannot happen without the support of parents. Parents are critical to the success of a child‚Äôs reading ability. Learning to read begins with oral vocabulary. This means babies should be read to even before birth. Additionally, babies toddlers and preschool age children should NOT spend time on a phone or iPad watching videos. Television time should also be limited to educational type shows, not just cartoons. Books should be readily available so that anyone can pick up a book and share the book with the child. Visits to the grocery store and Wal-Mart should also include conversations such as picking up a vegetable and showing and talking to the child about the vegetable. Oral vocabulary growth allows children later in life to make associations with books they are reading.
If you are a parent of a young child and you have not been exposing your child to books, please change your habits now. Books will make a much better gift than a toy. Grandparents, if your grandchildren are not being exposed to reading, please help educate the parents and reduce computer and screen time. Talking to your children will make a world of difference when they begin kindergarten. If changes are not made soon, we will have an abundance of third graders due to lack of reading exposure before entering school.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

The red car was at a complete stop behind a bus stopped at a train crossing. The blue Jeep was texting and driving. The driver of the red car is okay, shockingly, and luckily he was alone because a passenger likely would not have survived.
Please don‚Äôt text and drive. You are not special. You are not better at it than everybody else. You are distracted. Get over yourself. Think about other people and get off your damn phone while driving.

shared_text:
Coosa County School System
January 28 at 9:45 PM ¬∑

A Note from the Superintendent of Education
As I have been making my way from the office to the schools each day, I have been eyeing the former Avondale building. This building that sat abandoned for many years is now being spruced up. The transformation has been slow but finally, this week, a name has gone up on the building. This is definitely something very encouraging for Coosa County. A business based upon a trade; a trade reflective of woodworking and upholstering.
As you have heard throughout the news and social media markets, there is a high demand for tradesmen. The Coosa County School System has had several programs in the past such as building science, air conditioning and refrigeration and auto mechanics, which were very popular programs by the students but were discontinued well before my time due to not being able to find certified teachers or tradesmen willing to give up a higher salary to teach the trade. Programs that have been around, even when the other programs were available, and continue to be popular and viable programs in the school system are Business Office Management, Health Science, Family and Consumer Science and Agriscience.
These four programs continue to exist as an option for students to choose as a class without the actual career tech center building being open. while housed on the main campus at Central High School The building was closed because there has to be five viable programs in order to have a career tech center. We did not have five full programs due to the loss of EARNED teaching units at the high school. A school, such as Central High School, earns teaching units based upon the number of students enrolled in that school for the prior school year. To be precise, the enrollment is captured on the 20th day after Labor Day. With any drop in enrollment, there is a chance of losing a teaching unit. In the past, Central High School has been able to devote five teaching units specifically to the Career Tech Center because the number of teaching units did not create a hardship on the core classes needed that could not be adjusted in the areas of, mathematics, science, English and history. Unfortunately, the strategic maneuvering could not be maneuvered any more.
With the teaching units earned this past year, strategically planning options were not options anymore and the devoted five units did not qualify for a Career Tech Center. Are students offered career tech classes? YES. Do students participate in career tech classes? Yes. Do students have book work in career tech classes? Yes, as they always have in the past. Do students participate in hands-on instruction? Yes, as they always have in the past. Dual enrollment has been an option for trade pathways, FREE of CHARGE to high school students. Students have been participating in these programs, such as welding, for several years. Students now have an option to graduate from high school with an additional certificate from a technical program at Central Alabama Community College ready for the workforce. Part of each program is to support students in finding jobs in the field of certification. This December, we have already had one student to complete a program and several more that will be graduating high school in May with either a technical degree or a two year degree. Very impressive accomplishments of our students!
Close relationships with CACC has been critical in planning and preparing a schedule conducive to the high school schedule. Has is always been easy to accommodate the students with the classes they want to take? Not always, but special attention has been given to each student participating in these dual enrollment opportunities so that we can create a schedule that supports the program. The main thing to keep on the forefront is the student and their interest. If students are not interested in the program, they are wasting time. If students participate in a program of interest, they will excel and be ready for the job force when they graduate high school.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶
