shared_text: Coosa County School System
text: Coosa County School System

post_text:
I think we have all heard the saying, ‚ÄúEducation is the Key‚Äù. This can apply in every facet of life. Education is key when making any type of important decision; what college to attend, what job offer is best for me and my family, which foods it should eat on a prescribed diet, just to name a few. Being knowledgeable in the roles and responsibilities for the office of superintendent is important for everyone to know in order to understand the depth of responsibility and commitment.
According to the Alabama Association of School Boards, AASB, and the School Superintendents of Alabama, SSA, there are ten overall responsibilities: General Functions, Relationships, Meetings, Policy, Budget and Finance, Curriculum and Instruction, Personnel, Students, Facilities and Community Engagement. All of these topics have multiple roles or responsibilities reflective of each topic. I would like to share this information with everyone to show the depth of responsibility that goes into this position and depending upon the size of the system, how much more this position requires of the superintendent.
The General Function responsibility involves establishing a vision, focusing on raising student achievement, implementing board policies and overseeing daily operations, providing educational leadership for the staff, holding all employees accountable for system performance, identifying needs and reporting the needs to the board for action, initiating development and implementation of a strategic plan, monitors and apprises the board of state and national developments, and participates in professional development activities and whole board trainings. This first responsibility covers an array of responsibilities that drive the system. Raising student achievement and professional development are two very time consuming responsibilities in itself and are continuous day to day responsibilities.
Relationships, as with everything we do in a school system, are critical to success of the system. Overseeing the overall operation of the system and managing all personnel is a day to day responsibility. There are other key members of the system team that must support the superintendent in this area but without the support, additional challenges can arise. Respecting the decisions and opinions of the board and its members is critical. Being open minded about decisions allows opportunities to build trust with one another, such as Board members. Also, providing information to the board in a timely manner regarding information allows the board to make sound decisions based upon the information presented in advance. Keeping the board abreast of policy development and revision is important as well. The board must be given ample time to examine and study policy changes before decisions should be made.
Meetings is the third role and responsibility listed which reflect the role of the superintendent as the Chief Executive Officer, CEO, and secretary to the board as well as a member of the governance team. Assuring compliance with state law regarding meeting notices and maintenance of meeting records is important. Laws are in place with requirements regarding when, where and how meeting information is to be posted as well as the depth of meeting notes. The superintendent is responsible for developing the topics to present before the board and must provide a packet to board members in advance of the meeting to allow time to review and ask questions. All staff members and others relevant to each board agenda is notified of decisions made by the board following the board meeting. The superintendent must assure the board meets for all legally required sessions.
Policy can be an ever changing responsibility based upon the updates that are required through federal and state legislation. The superintendent advises the board regarding the need and when policy changes will be occurring. Drafts of the proposed changes are usually sent to system legal advisors first before being presented to the board members for adoption. Policy manuals must be made readily available to the board members and public, usually accessible through school system websites. Employees must be made aware of changes and educated on the changes and why. At times, policies may not necessarily be needed but procedures may be put into place to reflect expectations and policy. Keeping the policy on the forefront is an absolute.
Budget and Finance responsibilities are often the unseen backbone of a school system. The superintendent along with the board and the Chief School Financial Officer, CSFO, work to ensure the budget is aligned with system goals. Budget hearings are held in order to share with the public what expenditures are expected or have occurred. A budget must be approved yearly at a designated time of the year. A superintendent and CSFO must monitor the financial health of the system which may not always be a ‚Äúhealthy budget‚Äù. The board and staff must have clear and accurate information regarding the budget. The Superintendent works with the CSFO to develop a plan to remedy any deficits and/or audit findings. Most importantly, the superintendent MUST be willing to advocate for financial support.
Curriculum and Instruction is a must when it comes to the roles and responsibilities of the superintendent. With raising student achievement as one of the target general functions of a superintendent, creating a culture of high expectations for both students and staff is an absolute. The superintendent must advise the board on all student educational needs as well as evaluating the effectiveness of instructional programs. Leading the efforts of continuously improving teaching and learning is all day, every day. The superintendent works to keep the board abreast of the staff‚Äôs work regarding student achievement and program implementation.
Personnel roles and responsibilities reflect the superintendent recommending the employment, retention, promotion and termination of staff. A superintendent must foster a strong working relationship with staff and maintains the lines of communication. Additionally, the superintendent must ensure that all staff members are effectively supervised and evaluated. The superintendent delegates authority as appropriate based upon the job descriptions laid out for all staff members. The superintendent also serves as the board‚Äôs liaison to the staff and establishes professional development for them, as well.
The roles and responsibilities of students where the superintendent is concerned reflect a healthy climate for student growth and learning. Additionally, as mentioned earlier, evaluating the school programs in order to meet the needs of students is an absolute. The recommendation and implementation of policies for student support services is dependent upon student needs. First and foremost, policies and rules are established to maintain student safety, health and discipline.
Dependent upon the district‚Äôs needs, facilities play a role in the superintendent‚Äôs roles and responsibilities. The superintendent implements policies for the use, operation, maintenance and rental of system buildings, grounds and equipment. A superintendent must provide for the proper upkeep of the facilities and equipment as well. Priorities are set for long-term and preventative maintenance of the facilities and equipment yearly as well as working with architects, staff and consultants when necessary. The superintendent also recommends actions related to construction, closing, consolidation, and rezoning, which may or may not be popular recommendations.
Finally, the superintendent plays a critical role and responsibility in community engagement. It is important that the superintendent informs stakeholders about the system‚Äôs successes and challenges. There is also the expectation of the superintendent for the staff to engage parents in every possible way. The superintendent should be able to engage in dialog with stakeholders at all levels about issues facing the system. They must work with the news media and social media and build bridges between the system and key organizations and leaders.
I know this was a lengthy article but I felt it was important to get information out about the roles and responsibilities of a superintendent. As a general rule, we do not always know ALL about a person‚Äôs job. I think we should ask more people to shed light on the roles and responsibilities they are held accountable for each day. That is how we can understand things better but most importantly, support one another more.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

shared_text:
Coosa County School System
December 14, 2019 at 8:12 PM ¬∑

A Note from the Superintendent of Education
Our students are getting in the Christmas Spirit with only one week left of the first semester. That is so hard to believe!. This school year is quickly passing and not only students but others such as administrators and teachers must make every moment count.
I would like to conclude the series I began a couple of weeks ago, ‚ÄúEducation is the Key‚Äù. I have hopefully educated everyone in the roles and responsibilities of the superintendent and principal. Today, I would like to educate everyone on the roles and responsibilities of a teacher. As with all of these jobs comes various responsibilities.
According to Alabama Code 290-3-3-.03,the Alabama Core Teaching Standards, identify ten areas a teacher must address on a daily basis.
(1) Learner Development. The teacher understanding how learners grow and develop is critical, Recognizing that patterns of learning and development vary individually within and across the cognitive, linguistic, social, emotional, and physical areas, and designs and implements developmentally appropriate and challenging learning experiences plays a large role in exposing students to what is developmentally appropriate content for .students
(2) Learning Differences. The teacher using an understanding of individual differences and diverse cultures and communities to ensure inclusive learning environments that enable each learner to meet high standards is an important aspect to overall learning. Teachers must be in tune to cultural and individual differences of students in teach class.
(3) Learning Environments. The teacher working with others to create environments that support individual and collaborative learning and that encourage positive social interaction, active engagement in learning, and self-motivation is a must. Students should feel safe and non-threatened as learning occurs in various environments throughout the school each day..
(4) Content Knowledge. The teacher understanding the central concepts, tools of inquiry, and structures of the discipline(s) he or she teaches and creates learning experiences that make these aspects of the discipline accessible and meaningful for learners to assure mastery of the content is a daily goal. Students must have opportunities to investigate and follow guiding questions in order to develop thinking skills. Being told answers is not always the right direction to take. A productive struggle is necessary in order to build thinking skills..
(5) Application of Content The teacher understanding how to connect concepts and use differing perspectives to engage learners in critical thinking, creativity, and collaborative problem solving related to authentic local and global issues. Building background is key in order to spark thinking.
(6) Assessment The teacher understanding and using multiple methods of assessment to engage learners in their own growth, to monitor learner progress, and to guide the candidate‚Äôs and learner‚Äôs decision making. Students must be a part of the learning through self-evaluation
(7) Planning for Instruction Based on the appropriate Alabama Course(s) of Study, the teacher planning instruction that supports every student in meeting rigorous learning goals by drawing upon knowledge of content areas, curriculum, cross-disciplinary skills, and pedagogy, as well as knowledge of learners and the community context. This takes time order to develop lessons that support various levels and keeping focused on the outcome of each day‚Äôs lesson.
(8) Instructional Strategies. The teacher understanding and using a variety of instructional strategies to encourage learners to develop deep understanding of content areas and their connections, and to build skills to apply knowledge in meaningful ways. This will assist all involved in a lesson to be engaged.
(9) Professional Learning and Ethical Practice The teacher engaging in ongoing professional learning and uses evidence to continually evaluate his/her practice, particularly the effects of his/her choices and actions on others (learners, families, other professionals, and the community) and adapts practice to meet the needs of each learner. Teachers should never dread an opportunity for professional learning. Teachers should think of themselves as life-long learners.
(10) Leadership and Collaboration The teacher seeking appropriate leadership roles and opportunities to take responsibility for student learning, to collaborate with learners, families, colleagues, other school professionals, and community members to ensure learner growth, and to advance the profession. This is what build capacity in schools and develops the next level of leaders.
It would have been easy to go into more detail for each of the three articles, but unfortunately I am sure Christa appreciates me limiting the information to at least cover the surface. Teachers have MANY responsibilities and it times time to develop in all areas. I hope everyone realizes the depth of the roles and responsibilities of everyone in the school setting. I often hear, teachers are off in the summer. That is not really an accurate statement. Great teachers work all summer preparing for the upcoming school year. Remember, teachers are life-long learners.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

The teacher understanding and using a variety of instructional strategies to encourage learners to develop deep understanding of content areas and their connections, and to build skills to apply knowledge in meaningful ways. This will assist all involved in a lesson to be engaged.
(9) Professional Learning and Ethical Practice The teacher engaging in ongoing professional learning and uses evidence to continually evaluate his/her practice, particularly the effects of his/her choices and actions on others (learners, families, other professionals, and the community) and adapts practice to meet the needs of each learner. Teachers should never dread an opportunity for professional learning. Teachers should think of themselves as life-long learners.
(10) Leadership and Collaboration The teacher seeking appropriate leadership roles and opportunities to take responsibility for student learning, to collaborate with learners, families, colleagues, other school professionals, and community members to ensure learner growth, and to advance the profession. This is what build capacity in schools and develops the next level of leaders.
It would have been easy to go into more detail for each of the three articles, but unfortunately I am sure Christa appreciates me limiting the information to at least cover the surface. Teachers have MANY responsibilities and it times time to develop in all areas. I hope everyone realizes the depth of the roles and responsibilities of everyone in the school setting. I often hear, teachers are off in the summer. That is not really an accurate statement. Great teachers work all summer preparing for the upcoming school year. Remember, teachers are life-long learners.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

shared_text:
Coosa County School System
December 14, 2019 at 8:09 PM ¬∑

A Note from the Superintendent of Education
I hope everyone had a wonderful Thanksgiving holiday this past week. We all have so much to be thankful for whether it‚Äôs our family, health, job, or life in general. So often we take things for granted. Things can change so quickly. Living without regret and having forgiveness in our hearts is not always easy but is a necessity.
I would like to continue the series I began last week with ‚ÄúEducation is the Key‚Äù. The roles and responsibilities of a superintendent was the first focus. I hope everyone gained knowledge is that area. This week, I would like to shed light on the roles and responsibilities of a principal. According to
Alabama Code 16-24B-4. a principal and contract principal shall supervise the daily operation and management of personnel, finances, facilities, and other matters of the school or campus for which the principal and contract principal is responsible. A principal and contract principal shall assume the administrative responsibility and instructional leadership, as directed by the chief executive officer, consistent with the policies of the employing board, for the planning, management, operation, and evaluation of the education program of each school or campus under the responsibility of the principal and contract principal.
All principals in the Coosa County School System are contract principals, because they were hired after July 1, 2000 reflective of the Teacher Accountability Act. Principals do not earn tenure under the Teacher Accountability Act. A first year principal with no previous experience in a particular system is considered a probationary principal. A principal candidate can be hired on a probationary contract for one or two years dependent upon the Board‚Äôs desire. If a newly hired principal has had experience in another Alabama system, the principal can only be hired as a one year probationary principal according to the law. It is the responsibility of the superintendent to evaluate the principals, however, there is no requirement to evaluate probationary principals under the Act. There is also no consequence for failing to annually evaluate probationary principals. Unlike probationary principals, contract principals must be evaluated annually using the evaluation instrument approved by the State Department of Education. If the contract principal is not properly evaluated at any point, his contract shall be extended one year for every year the evaluation is not completed, up to a maximum of three years. All contract principals must be evaluated each year. Without an evaluation, a year extension must be given for every year not evaluated. An employing board may cancel the contract of a contract principal for cause at any time for any of the following reasons: immorality, insubordination, neglect of duty, conviction of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude, failure to fulfill the duties and responsibilities imposed upon principals by this code, willful failure to comply with board policy, a justifiable decrease in the number of positions due to decreased enrollment or decreased funding, failure to maintain his or her certificate in a current status, other good and just cause, incompetency, and failure to perform duties in a satisfactory manner.
Supervision plays a large role in the day to day operations of the school. Principals must ensure the buildings are safe and free from harmful situations. Holding all employees and staff members responsible for their delegation is an absolute in supervision. There is no way possible a principal can physically oversee students and potential situations. It is necessary that a principal sets the expectation of how, when and where each employee supports in supervision as described in Board policy. Having dependable and accountable employees help to make the responsibility of a principal less taxing. Well prepared teachers allow for less discipline and more learning. As the instructional leader, the principal sets the expectation for being well prepared and well versed in the standards and curriculum. The principal supports teachers in becoming well versed in management, instruction, communication and other areas pertinent to the vision of the school. The principal is primarily in charge of evaluating all teachers. The principal must also work with teachers in order to improve in ‚Äúareas of concern‚Äù.
Continuous improvement should reflect the needs of the school based upon assessments and other data. An instructional leader spends the majority of their time in the classrooms, collecting data and supporting instruction. The instructional leader should be an effective use of resources. It isn‚Äôt sufficient for principals to just know their faculty‚Äôs strengths and weaknesses. If specific resources can benefit the staff, the principal should be ready and prepared to provide them. They should also clearly recognize that teachers thrive on being appreciated and acknowledged for good performance. Principals must have strong communication skills. Of course, instructional principals should be excellent communicators. Interpersonal or people skills are crucial to the success of a principal. They must be able to communicate their beliefs pertaining to education, including the conviction that every student is capable of learning. These skills inspire trust, spark motivation and empower teachers and students. Additionally, instructional leaders must serve as an instructional resource. Teachers rely on principals and other administration officials to be sources of information related to effective instructional practices and current trends in education. Instructional leaders should be tuned in to all of the pertinent issues and current events related to curriculum, effective assessment, and pedagogical strategies. Lastly, good principals should be a positive, vibrant and visible presence in the school. Modeling behaviors of learning, focusing on learning objectives, and leading by example are crucial to the success of an instructional principal. In addition to these four qualities, a successful instructional principal should also have excellent planning and observation skills as well as proficiency in research and evaluation of both staff and student performance. Principals, like teachers, spend hours after school, planning, preparing, documenting, organizing and problem-solving. Their job responsibilities are critical to the success of the school.
Finances reflect the earnings and expenditures of the school. Some may think a school does not have bills to pay, but unfortunately, they do, power, water, Xerox copies, toilet paper, cleaning supplies, wax and stripper, yard maintenance, etc. This responsibility takes knowledge in what will profit the school most but also weighing in on the needs of the maintenance of the school. Facilities must be kept-up by the school. Major work would be addressed through the superintendent‚Äôs office. Additionally, the school must keep budgets of various programs used in the school. Most of the budgets must be approved by the faculty or a team from the faculty.
This article addressed many highlights of a principal‚Äôs responsibility. The content may have been lengthy, but I feel it is important that we learn roles and responsibilities of key players in the school system. The more questions we ask, the more we will learn.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

post_text:
A Note from the Superintendent of Education
Our students are getting in the Christmas Spirit with only one week left of the first semester. That is so hard to believe!. This school year is quickly passing and not only students but others such as administrators and teachers must make every moment count.
I would like to conclude the series I began a couple of weeks ago, ‚ÄúEducation is the Key‚Äù. I have hopefully educated everyone in the roles and responsibilities of the superintendent and principal. Today, I would like to educate everyone on the roles and responsibilities of a teacher. As with all of these jobs comes various responsibilities.
According to Alabama Code 290-3-3-.03,the Alabama Core Teaching Standards, identify ten areas a teacher must address on a daily basis.
(1) Learner Development. The teacher understanding how learners grow and develop is critical, Recognizing that patterns of learning and development vary individually within and across the cognitive, linguistic, social, emotional, and physical areas, and designs and implements developmentally appropriate and challenging learning experiences plays a large role in exposing students to what is developmentally appropriate content for .students
(2) Learning Differences. The teacher using an understanding of individual differences and diverse cultures and communities to ensure inclusive learning environments that enable each learner to meet high standards is an important aspect to overall learning. Teachers must be in tune to cultural and individual differences of students in teach class.
(3) Learning Environments. The teacher working with others to create environments that support individual and collaborative learning and that encourage positive social interaction, active engagement in learning, and self-motivation is a must. Students should feel safe and non-threatened as learning occurs in various environments throughout the school each day..
(4) Content Knowledge. The teacher understanding the central concepts, tools of inquiry, and structures of the discipline(s) he or she teaches and creates learning experiences that make these aspects of the discipline accessible and meaningful for learners to assure mastery of the content is a daily goal. Students must have opportunities to investigate and follow guiding questions in order to develop thinking skills. Being told answers is not always the right direction to take. A productive struggle is necessary in order to build thinking skills..
(5) Application of Content The teacher understanding how to connect concepts and use differing perspectives to engage learners in critical thinking, creativity, and collaborative problem solving related to authentic local and global issues. Building background is key in order to spark thinking.
(6) Assessment The teacher understanding and using multiple methods of assessment to engage learners in their own growth, to monitor learner progress, and to guide the candidate‚Äôs and learner‚Äôs decision making. Students must be a part of the learning through self-evaluation
(7) Planning for Instruction Based on the appropriate Alabama Course(s) of Study, the teacher planning instruction that supports every student in meeting rigorous learning goals by drawing upon knowledge of content areas, curriculum, cross-disciplinary skills, and pedagogy, as well as knowledge of learners and the community context. This takes time order to develop lessons that support various levels and keeping focused on the outcome of each day‚Äôs lesson.
(8) Instructional Strategies. The teacher understanding and using a variety of instructional strategies to encourage learners to develop deep understanding of content areas and their connections, and to build skills to apply knowledge in meaningful ways. This will assist all involved in a lesson to be engaged.
(9) Professional Learning and Ethical Practice The teacher engaging in ongoing professional learning and uses evidence to continually evaluate his/her practice, particularly the effects of his/her choices and actions on others (learners, families, other professionals, and the community) and adapts practice to meet the needs of each learner. Teachers should never dread an opportunity for professional learning. Teachers should think of themselves as life-long learners.
(10) Leadership and Collaboration The teacher seeking appropriate leadership roles and opportunities to take responsibility for student learning, to collaborate with learners, families, colleagues, other school professionals, and community members to ensure learner growth, and to advance the profession. This is what build capacity in schools and develops the next level of leaders.
It would have been easy to go into more detail for each of the three articles, but unfortunately I am sure Christa appreciates me limiting the information to at least cover the surface. Teachers have MANY responsibilities and it times time to develop in all areas. I hope everyone realizes the depth of the roles and responsibilities of everyone in the school setting. I often hear, teachers are off in the summer. That is not really an accurate statement. Great teachers work all summer preparing for the upcoming school year. Remember, teachers are life-long learners.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶
text:
A Note from the Superintendent of Education
Our students are getting in the Christmas Spirit with only one week left of the first semester. That is so hard to believe!. This school year is quickly passing and not only students but others such as administrators and teachers must make every moment count.
I would like to conclude the series I began a couple of weeks ago, ‚ÄúEducation is the Key‚Äù. I have hopefully educated everyone in the roles and responsibilities of the superintendent and principal. Today, I would like to educate everyone on the roles and responsibilities of a teacher. As with all of these jobs comes various responsibilities.
According to Alabama Code 290-3-3-.03,the Alabama Core Teaching Standards, identify ten areas a teacher must address on a daily basis.
(1) Learner Development. The teacher understanding how learners grow and develop is critical, Recognizing that patterns of learning and development vary individually within and across the cognitive, linguistic, social, emotional, and physical areas, and designs and implements developmentally appropriate and challenging learning experiences plays a large role in exposing students to what is developmentally appropriate content for .students
(2) Learning Differences. The teacher using an understanding of individual differences and diverse cultures and communities to ensure inclusive learning environments that enable each learner to meet high standards is an important aspect to overall learning. Teachers must be in tune to cultural and individual differences of students in teach class.
(3) Learning Environments. The teacher working with others to create environments that support individual and collaborative learning and that encourage positive social interaction, active engagement in learning, and self-motivation is a must. Students should feel safe and non-threatened as learning occurs in various environments throughout the school each day..
(4) Content Knowledge. The teacher understanding the central concepts, tools of inquiry, and structures of the discipline(s) he or she teaches and creates learning experiences that make these aspects of the discipline accessible and meaningful for learners to assure mastery of the content is a daily goal. Students must have opportunities to investigate and follow guiding questions in order to develop thinking skills. Being told answers is not always the right direction to take. A productive struggle is necessary in order to build thinking skills..
(5) Application of Content The teacher understanding how to connect concepts and use differing perspectives to engage learners in critical thinking, creativity, and collaborative problem solving related to authentic local and global issues. Building background is key in order to spark thinking.
(6) Assessment The teacher understanding and using multiple methods of assessment to engage learners in their own growth, to monitor learner progress, and to guide the candidate‚Äôs and learner‚Äôs decision making. Students must be a part of the learning through self-evaluation
(7) Planning for Instruction Based on the appropriate Alabama Course(s) of Study, the teacher planning instruction that supports every student in meeting rigorous learning goals by drawing upon knowledge of content areas, curriculum, cross-disciplinary skills, and pedagogy, as well as knowledge of learners and the community context. This takes time order to develop lessons that support various levels and keeping focused on the outcome of each day‚Äôs lesson.
(8) Instructional Strategies. The teacher understanding and using a variety of instructional strategies to encourage learners to develop deep understanding of content areas and their connections, and to build skills to apply knowledge in meaningful ways. This will assist all involved in a lesson to be engaged.
(9) Professional Learning and Ethical Practice The teacher engaging in ongoing professional learning and uses evidence to continually evaluate his/her practice, particularly the effects of his/her choices and actions on others (learners, families, other professionals, and the community) and adapts practice to meet the needs of each learner. Teachers should never dread an opportunity for professional learning. Teachers should think of themselves as life-long learners.
(10) Leadership and Collaboration The teacher seeking appropriate leadership roles and opportunities to take responsibility for student learning, to collaborate with learners, families, colleagues, other school professionals, and community members to ensure learner growth, and to advance the profession. This is what build capacity in schools and develops the next level of leaders.
It would have been easy to go into more detail for each of the three articles, but unfortunately I am sure Christa appreciates me limiting the information to at least cover the surface. Teachers have MANY responsibilities and it times time to develop in all areas. I hope everyone realizes the depth of the roles and responsibilities of everyone in the school setting. I often hear, teachers are off in the summer. That is not really an accurate statement. Great teachers work all summer preparing for the upcoming school year. Remember, teachers are life-long learners.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

shared_text:
Coosa County School System
December 14, 2019 at 8:09 PM ¬∑

A Note from the Superintendent of Education
I hope everyone had a wonderful Thanksgiving holiday this past week. We all have so much to be thankful for whether it‚Äôs our family, health, job, or life in general. So often we take things for granted. Things can change so quickly. Living without regret and having forgiveness in our hearts is not always easy but is a necessity.
I would like to continue the series I began last week with ‚ÄúEducation is the Key‚Äù. The roles and responsibilities of a superintendent was the first focus. I hope everyone gained knowledge is that area. This week, I would like to shed light on the roles and responsibilities of a principal. According to
Alabama Code 16-24B-4. a principal and contract principal shall supervise the daily operation and management of personnel, finances, facilities, and other matters of the school or campus for which the principal and contract principal is responsible. A principal and contract principal shall assume the administrative responsibility and instructional leadership, as directed by the chief executive officer, consistent with the policies of the employing board, for the planning, management, operation, and evaluation of the education program of each school or campus under the responsibility of the principal and contract principal.
All principals in the Coosa County School System are contract principals, because they were hired after July 1, 2000 reflective of the Teacher Accountability Act. Principals do not earn tenure under the Teacher Accountability Act. A first year principal with no previous experience in a particular system is considered a probationary principal. A principal candidate can be hired on a probationary contract for one or two years dependent upon the Board‚Äôs desire. If a newly hired principal has had experience in another Alabama system, the principal can only be hired as a one year probationary principal according to the law. It is the responsibility of the superintendent to evaluate the principals, however, there is no requirement to evaluate probationary principals under the Act. There is also no consequence for failing to annually evaluate probationary principals. Unlike probationary principals, contract principals must be evaluated annually using the evaluation instrument approved by the State Department of Education. If the contract principal is not properly evaluated at any point, his contract shall be extended one year for every year the evaluation is not completed, up to a maximum of three years. All contract principals must be evaluated each year. Without an evaluation, a year extension must be given for every year not evaluated. An employing board may cancel the contract of a contract principal for cause at any time for any of the following reasons: immorality, insubordination, neglect of duty, conviction of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude, failure to fulfill the duties and responsibilities imposed upon principals by this code, willful failure to comply with board policy, a justifiable decrease in the number of positions due to decreased enrollment or decreased funding, failure to maintain his or her certificate in a current status, other good and just cause, incompetency, and failure to perform duties in a satisfactory manner.
Supervision plays a large role in the day to day operations of the school. Principals must ensure the buildings are safe and free from harmful situations. Holding all employees and staff members responsible for their delegation is an absolute in supervision. There is no way possible a principal can physically oversee students and potential situations. It is necessary that a principal sets the expectation of how, when and where each employee supports in supervision as described in Board policy. Having dependable and accountable employees help to make the responsibility of a principal less taxing. Well prepared teachers allow for less discipline and more learning. As the instructional leader, the principal sets the expectation for being well prepared and well versed in the standards and curriculum. The principal supports teachers in becoming well versed in management, instruction, communication and other areas pertinent to the vision of the school. The principal is primarily in charge of evaluating all teachers. The principal must also work with teachers in order to improve in ‚Äúareas of concern‚Äù.
Continuous improvement should reflect the needs of the school based upon assessments and other data. An instructional leader spends the majority of their time in the classrooms, collecting data and supporting instruction. The instructional leader should be an effective use of resources. It isn‚Äôt sufficient for principals to just know their faculty‚Äôs strengths and weaknesses. If specific resources can benefit the staff, the principal should be ready and prepared to provide them. They should also clearly recognize that teachers thrive on being appreciated and acknowledged for good performance. Principals must have strong communication skills. Of course, instructional principals should be excellent communicators. Interpersonal or people skills are crucial to the success of a principal. They must be able to communicate their beliefs pertaining to education, including the conviction that every student is capable of learning. These skills inspire trust, spark motivation and empower teachers and students. Additionally, instructional leaders must serve as an instructional resource. Teachers rely on principals and other administration officials to be sources of information related to effective instructional practices and current trends in education. Instructional leaders should be tuned in to all of the pertinent issues and current events related to curriculum, effective assessment, and pedagogical strategies. Lastly, good principals should be a positive, vibrant and visible presence in the school. Modeling behaviors of learning, focusing on learning objectives, and leading by example are crucial to the success of an instructional principal. In addition to these four qualities, a successful instructional principal should also have excellent planning and observation skills as well as proficiency in research and evaluation of both staff and student performance. Principals, like teachers, spend hours after school, planning, preparing, documenting, organizing and problem-solving. Their job responsibilities are critical to the success of the school.
Finances reflect the earnings and expenditures of the school. Some may think a school does not have bills to pay, but unfortunately, they do, power, water, Xerox copies, toilet paper, cleaning supplies, wax and stripper, yard maintenance, etc. This responsibility takes knowledge in what will profit the school most but also weighing in on the needs of the maintenance of the school. Facilities must be kept-up by the school. Major work would be addressed through the superintendent‚Äôs office. Additionally, the school must keep budgets of various programs used in the school. Most of the budgets must be approved by the faculty or a team from the faculty.
This article addressed many highlights of a principal‚Äôs responsibility. The content may have been lengthy, but I feel it is important that we learn roles and responsibilities of key players in the school system. The more questions we ask, the more we will learn.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

I would like to continue the series I began last week with ‚ÄúEducation is the Key‚Äù. The roles and responsibilities of a superintendent was the first focus. I hope everyone gained knowledge is that area. This week, I would like to shed light on the roles and responsibilities of a principal. According to
Alabama Code 16-24B-4. a principal and contract principal shall supervise the daily operation and management of personnel, finances, facilities, and other matters of the school or campus for which the principal and contract principal is responsible. A principal and contract principal shall assume the administrative responsibility and instructional leadership, as directed by the chief executive officer, consistent with the policies of the employing board, for the planning, management, operation, and evaluation of the education program of each school or campus under the responsibility of the principal and contract principal.
All principals in the Coosa County School System are contract principals, because they were hired after July 1, 2000 reflective of the Teacher Accountability Act. Principals do not earn tenure under the Teacher Accountability Act. A first year principal with no previous experience in a particular system is considered a probationary principal. A principal candidate can be hired on a probationary contract for one or two years dependent upon the Board‚Äôs desire. If a newly hired principal has had experience in another Alabama system, the principal can only be hired as a one year probationary principal according to the law. It is the responsibility of the superintendent to evaluate the principals, however, there is no requirement to evaluate probationary principals under the Act. There is also no consequence for failing to annually evaluate probationary principals. Unlike probationary principals, contract principals must be evaluated annually using the evaluation instrument approved by the State Department of Education. If the contract principal is not properly evaluated at any point, his contract shall be extended one year for every year the evaluation is not completed, up to a maximum of three years. All contract principals must be evaluated each year. Without an evaluation, a year extension must be given for every year not evaluated. An employing board may cancel the contract of a contract principal for cause at any time for any of the following reasons: immorality, insubordination, neglect of duty, conviction of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude, failure to fulfill the duties and responsibilities imposed upon principals by this code, willful failure to comply with board policy, a justifiable decrease in the number of positions due to decreased enrollment or decreased funding, failure to maintain his or her certificate in a current status, other good and just cause, incompetency, and failure to perform duties in a satisfactory manner.
Supervision plays a large role in the day to day operations of the school. Principals must ensure the buildings are safe and free from harmful situations. Holding all employees and staff members responsible for their delegation is an absolute in supervision. There is no way possible a principal can physically oversee students and potential situations. It is necessary that a principal sets the expectation of how, when and where each employee supports in supervision as described in Board policy. Having dependable and accountable employees help to make the responsibility of a principal less taxing. Well prepared teachers allow for less discipline and more learning. As the instructional leader, the principal sets the expectation for being well prepared and well versed in the standards and curriculum. The principal supports teachers in becoming well versed in management, instruction, communication and other areas pertinent to the vision of the school. The principal is primarily in charge of evaluating all teachers. The principal must also work with teachers in order to improve in ‚Äúareas of concern‚Äù.
Continuous improvement should reflect the needs of the school based upon assessments and other data. An instructional leader spends the majority of their time in the classrooms, collecting data and supporting instruction. The instructional leader should be an effective use of resources. It isn‚Äôt sufficient for principals to just know their faculty‚Äôs strengths and weaknesses. If specific resources can benefit the staff, the principal should be ready and prepared to provide them. They should also clearly recognize that teachers thrive on being appreciated and acknowledged for good performance. Principals must have strong communication skills. Of course, instructional principals should be excellent communicators. Interpersonal or people skills are crucial to the success of a principal. They must be able to communicate their beliefs pertaining to education, including the conviction that every student is capable of learning. These skills inspire trust, spark motivation and empower teachers and students. Additionally, instructional leaders must serve as an instructional resource. Teachers rely on principals and other administration officials to be sources of information related to effective instructional practices and current trends in education. Instructional leaders should be tuned in to all of the pertinent issues and current events related to curriculum, effective assessment, and pedagogical strategies. Lastly, good principals should be a positive, vibrant and visible presence in the school. Modeling behaviors of learning, focusing on learning objectives, and leading by example are crucial to the success of an instructional principal. In addition to these four qualities, a successful instructional principal should also have excellent planning and observation skills as well as proficiency in research and evaluation of both staff and student performance. Principals, like teachers, spend hours after school, planning, preparing, documenting, organizing and problem-solving. Their job responsibilities are critical to the success of the school.
Finances reflect the earnings and expenditures of the school. Some may think a school does not have bills to pay, but unfortunately, they do, power, water, Xerox copies, toilet paper, cleaning supplies, wax and stripper, yard maintenance, etc. This responsibility takes knowledge in what will profit the school most but also weighing in on the needs of the maintenance of the school. Facilities must be kept-up by the school. Major work would be addressed through the superintendent‚Äôs office. Additionally, the school must keep budgets of various programs used in the school. Most of the budgets must be approved by the faculty or a team from the faculty.
This article addressed many highlights of a principal‚Äôs responsibility. The content may have been lengthy, but I feel it is important that we learn roles and responsibilities of key players in the school system. The more questions we ask, the more we will learn.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

post_text: Coosa County Students are Better than Yours!! Please read and share!!
shared_text:
Coosa County School System
November 23, 2019 at 1:58 AM ¬∑

A Note from the Superintendent of Education
I have Thanksgiving on my mind since the schools had their annual Thanksgiving meal this week. Thanks so much to the Central Cafeteria staff that began working a week in advance to have everything just right for this meal and the guests who come to visit. In reality, Thanksgiving should be every day. Sometimes we take for granted things that we are thankful for but quite often, we show thankfulness rather than verbally mentioning it.
Speaking of verbally expressing thankfulness, it is not often that the Superintendent‚Äôs office gets a call from parents expressing how much they appreciate the school system and what the school system has meant to them and their children. I can attest, calls like this do happen and I cannot express to you how meaningful the positivity is to hear when those calls occur. I would like to let this article reflect this phone call and the gratitude shown to the school system by this single mom.
A couple of months ago, a parent calls and tells me who she is and begins sharing with me how upset she gets when others begin downing the school system. She proceeds to remind me of how the school system has supported her children through special needs, regular classes and college courses. As the conversation continues, she shares that one child was in pre-K classes and needed supports through speech and other special supports. Because the child received interventions early, these supports were not needed for a long period of time. She continues on as her children progress through elementary school and how they worked hard to earn good grades. But the accolades did not stop there. She continues through middle and high school as well when she mentions her children both being on the Advanced Diploma, working and participating in dual enrollment classes. She discussed her oldest child graduating and how he has worked and is doing well in college along with holding down a job.
Her youngest has been participating in college activities and classes since the summer prior to his ninth grade year. This student was asked to participate in the summer STEM camp held at CACC. I called the mom and explained the opportunity for STEM camp and thought her child would be an excellent candidate. Actually, several students were recommended by me to participate and other participated as well. Mom allowed her son to participate and from that experience on, other opportunities opened up for her child through dual enrollment. One opportunity was being contacted by one of the deans on the Alexander City Campus asking her son to participate in a project competition called Project MFG, Make, Focus, Grow, Shaping the Next Generation of American Manufacturing. This student was one of three students selected for the competition and he happened to be the only dual enrollment student, a Central High School, Coosa County student. For this recognition, this dual enrollment high school student from the Coosa County School System won $500 and a scholarship from Auburn University. Additional recognition includes letters of Academic Achievement for being named to the President‚Äôs List for Central Alabama Community College. This student is also pictured on the MFG website showing off his welding skills gained through dual enrollment. The Coosa County School System is so proud of one of our many STAR students, Cody Bussie, for all he has accomplished in high school. Just think he will be graduating in May and still has time to accomplish even more. Attached, you will find a picture of the Project MFG website featuring Central High School‚Äôs Cody Bussie, Coosa County‚Äôs own award winning dual enrollment student in welding attire.
Not only do I want to express thankfulness to Cody for helping the Coosa County School System shine in areas of strength for him but I also want to show thankfulness to his mom, Shana Bussie, for stepping up and sharing with others what the Coosa County School System has to offer. It would be so easy for everyone to listen to negativity and even chime in at times but Shana was bold enough to share what truly happened in the Coosa County School System the past 15 years with her children, bold enough to call the superintendent‚Äôs office and share the positive things. I hope they do not mind me using this story to share with everyone but this story needed to be told and at a time of thankfulness, I believe this was the perfect time.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

Coosa County Students are Better than Yours!! Please read and share!!

Coosa County School System
November 23, 2019 at 1:58 AM ¬∑

A Note from the Superintendent of Education
I have Thanksgiving on my mind since the schools had their annual Thanksgiving meal this week. Thanks so much to the Central Cafeteria staff that began working a week in advance to have everything just right for this meal and the guests who come to visit. In reality, Thanksgiving should be every day. Sometimes we take for granted things that we are thankful for but quite often, we show thankfulness rather than verbally mentioning it.
Speaking of verbally expressing thankfulness, it is not often that the Superintendent‚Äôs office gets a call from parents expressing how much they appreciate the school system and what the school system has meant to them and their children. I can attest, calls like this do happen and I cannot express to you how meaningful the positivity is to hear when those calls occur. I would like to let this article reflect this phone call and the gratitude shown to the school system by this single mom.
A couple of months ago, a parent calls and tells me who she is and begins sharing with me how upset she gets when others begin downing the school system. She proceeds to remind me of how the school system has supported her children through special needs, regular classes and college courses. As the conversation continues, she shares that one child was in pre-K classes and needed supports through speech and other special supports. Because the child received interventions early, these supports were not needed for a long period of time. She continues on as her children progress through elementary school and how they worked hard to earn good grades. But the accolades did not stop there. She continues through middle and high school as well when she mentions her children both being on the Advanced Diploma, working and participating in dual enrollment classes. She discussed her oldest child graduating and how he has worked and is doing well in college along with holding down a job.
Her youngest has been participating in college activities and classes since the summer prior to his ninth grade year. This student was asked to participate in the summer STEM camp held at CACC. I called the mom and explained the opportunity for STEM camp and thought her child would be an excellent candidate. Actually, several students were recommended by me to participate and other participated as well. Mom allowed her son to participate and from that experience on, other opportunities opened up for her child through dual enrollment. One opportunity was being contacted by one of the deans on the Alexander City Campus asking her son to participate in a project competition called Project MFG, Make, Focus, Grow, Shaping the Next Generation of American Manufacturing. This student was one of three students selected for the competition and he happened to be the only dual enrollment student, a Central High School, Coosa County student. For this recognition, this dual enrollment high school student from the Coosa County School System won $500 and a scholarship from Auburn University. Additional recognition includes letters of Academic Achievement for being named to the President‚Äôs List for Central Alabama Community College. This student is also pictured on the MFG website showing off his welding skills gained through dual enrollment. The Coosa County School System is so proud of one of our many STAR students, Cody Bussie, for all he has accomplished in high school. Just think he will be graduating in May and still has time to accomplish even more. Attached, you will find a picture of the Project MFG website featuring Central High School‚Äôs Cody Bussie, Coosa County‚Äôs own award winning dual enrollment student in welding attire.
Not only do I want to express thankfulness to Cody for helping the Coosa County School System shine in areas of strength for him but I also want to show thankfulness to his mom, Shana Bussie, for stepping up and sharing with others what the Coosa County School System has to offer. It would be so easy for everyone to listen to negativity and even chime in at times but Shana was bold enough to share what truly happened in the Coosa County School System the past 15 years with her children, bold enough to call the superintendent‚Äôs office and share the positive things. I hope they do not mind me using this story to share with everyone but this story needed to be told and at a time of thankfulness, I believe this was the perfect time.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

She proceeds to remind me of how the school system has supported her children through special needs, regular classes and college courses. As the conversation continues, she shares that one child was in pre-K classes and needed supports through speech and other special supports. Because the child received interventions early, these supports were not needed for a long period of time. She continues on as her children progress through elementary school and how they worked hard to earn good grades. But the accolades did not stop there. She continues through middle and high school as well when she mentions her children both being on the Advanced Diploma, working and participating in dual enrollment classes. She discussed her oldest child graduating and how he has worked and is doing well in college along with holding down a job.
Her youngest has been participating in college activities and classes since the summer prior to his ninth grade year. This student was asked to participate in the summer STEM camp held at CACC. I called the mom and explained the opportunity for STEM camp and thought her child would be an excellent candidate. Actually, several students were recommended by me to participate and other participated as well. Mom allowed her son to participate and from that experience on, other opportunities opened up for her child through dual enrollment. One opportunity was being contacted by one of the deans on the Alexander City Campus asking her son to participate in a project competition called Project MFG, Make, Focus, Grow, Shaping the Next Generation of American Manufacturing. This student was one of three students selected for the competition and he happened to be the only dual enrollment student, a Central High School, Coosa County student. For this recognition, this dual enrollment high school student from the Coosa County School System won $500 and a scholarship from Auburn University. Additional recognition includes letters of Academic Achievement for being named to the President‚Äôs List for Central Alabama Community College. This student is also pictured on the MFG website showing off his welding skills gained through dual enrollment. The Coosa County School System is so proud of one of our many STAR students, Cody Bussie, for all he has accomplished in high school. Just think he will be graduating in May and still has time to accomplish even more. Attached, you will find a picture of the Project MFG website featuring Central High School‚Äôs Cody Bussie, Coosa County‚Äôs own award winning dual enrollment student in welding attire.
Not only do I want to express thankfulness to Cody for helping the Coosa County School System shine in areas of strength for him but I also want to show thankfulness to his mom, Shana Bussie, for stepping up and sharing with others what the Coosa County School System has to offer. It would be so easy for everyone to listen to negativity and even chime in at times but Shana was bold enough to share what truly happened in the Coosa County School System the past 15 years with her children, bold enough to call the superintendent‚Äôs office and share the positive things. I hope they do not mind me using this story to share with everyone but this story needed to be told and at a time of thankfulness, I believe this was the perfect time.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶
text:
A Note from the Superintendent of Education
I have Thanksgiving on my mind since the schools had their annual Thanksgiving meal this week. Thanks so much to the Central Cafeteria staff that began working a week in advance to have everything just right for this meal and the guests who come to visit. In reality, Thanksgiving should be every day. Sometimes we take for granted things that we are thankful for but quite often, we show thankfulness rather than verbally mentioning it.
Speaking of verbally expressing thankfulness, it is not often that the Superintendent‚Äôs office gets a call from parents expressing how much they appreciate the school system and what the school system has meant to them and their children. I can attest, calls like this do happen and I cannot express to you how meaningful the positivity is to hear when those calls occur. I would like to let this article reflect this phone call and the gratitude shown to the school system by this single mom.
A couple of months ago, a parent calls and tells me who she is and begins sharing with me how upset she gets when others begin downing the school system. She proceeds to remind me of how the school system has supported her children through special needs, regular classes and college courses. I called the mom and explained the opportunity for STEM camp and thought her child would be an excellent candidate. The Coosa County School System is so proud of one of our many STAR students, Cody Bussie, for all he has accomplished in high school. Not only do I want to express thankfulness to Cody for helping the Coosa County School System shine in areas of strength for him but I also want to show thankfulness to his mom, Shana Bussie, for stepping up and sharing with others what the Coosa County School System has to offer. It would be so easy for everyone to listen to negativity and even chime in at times but Shana was bold enough to share what truly happened in the Coosa County School System the past 15 years with her children, bold enough to call the superintendent‚Äôs office and share the positive things. I hope they do not mind me using this story to share with everyone but this story needed to be told and at a time of thankfulness, I believe this was the perfect time.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

post_text:
A Note from the Superintendent of Education
I hope everyone is faring well with the cold wintery blast we have had this week. I heard someone say, ‚Äúonly in Alabama can you experience spring, summer, winter and fall all in one day‚Äù. I think we all can attest to that statement. If this is a sign of what the winter will bring, we had better get prepared.
In the last article, I focused on Veterans Day but today I would like to focus on community support. This past Friday, not only did the schools celebrate our veterans but we also supported the students at Central High School with many thanks to the Children‚Äôs Policy Council. A job fair has been held the past few years with the support of the Children‚Äôs Policy Council headed up by professional ‚Äúvolunteer‚Äù, Marty Rittmann. Mrs. Rittmann, a former teacher in the Coosa County School System, leads the Children‚Äôs Policy Council.
Some of you may have never heard of the Children‚Äôs Policy Council but is an Alabama Law Section 26-24-34 (Acts 1990, No. 90-674, p. 1304, ¬ß17; Act 2000-612, p. 1226, ¬ß1; ¬ß12-15-134; amended and renumbered by Act 2008-277, p. 441, ¬ß28; Act 2015-160, ¬ß1.) plays a very important role in data collection of children per county. The County Children‚Äôs Policy Council reviews the needs of children in the county and how local agencies and departments can work together more efficiently and effectively to serve the children in their area. Local teams submit an annual report to the Department of Children's Affairs by July 1 of each year on local services provided to children, local needs of children, and recommendations of the county children's policy council based on data from the previous fiscal year ending September 30. The local resource guides are used by the State Children's Policy Council in compiling a state resource guide which is distributed to the general public and to agencies and organizations serving children.
The project for Coosa County the past few years has focused on a job fair for Central High School students. Different agencies, such as Head Start, Altapointe, Coosa County School System, SAFE, United Way and the local Juvenile Judicial System, just to name a few, work together to bring in not only job resources but higher education options as well. These entities showcase what they have to offer students and in-turn, the students collect information and resources of interest, seeking options for future opportunities. Events like this cannot be carried out without the partnership of others. The school system could never create an event like this without hours of planning, extra personnel, and time getting things together. I cannot express the appreciation the school system has for this TEAM effort that occurs in COOSA COUNTY. This is what makes community support so great for the school system. As the Superintendent of Coosa County Schools, I have felt that it is important to become a part of each community in the county by participating in as many events as possible over the past years. As I have mentioned in a couple of previous articles, a school system is only as strong as it‚Äôs community, and with only one feeder pattern in the county, the school system depends upon many services the county can provide the school system.
Again, this group effort that has occurred in Coosa County over the past few years is a testament to the commitment the citizens and resources in and around Coosa County have toward the school system. The support shown is overwhelming and with the small staff in the school system, an event like this would not be possible without the support. Thanks to all!
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶
