post_text:
A Note from the Superintendent of Education
I would like to begin this article thanking the veterans of Coosa County. I attended the Town of Rockford‚Äôs celebration last Saturday. It was such an honor to not only be among five World War II Coosa Countians, but also many other veterans who made sacrifices for our country. The depth of sacrifice truly cannot be measured. I wonder if many of us truly think about ALL of the sacrifices that are made in order to serve our wonderful country. Many have lost time with families; families that may not have been the same once the time served had ended. Parents passed away. Spouses no longer were spouses. Children became young adults. Siblings may not have that close knit connection as before. Communities changed. Neighbors moved away. Many things changed during the time of sacrifice.
And then there is the veteran; aged, with possible physical, emotional, mental and spiritual differences trying to put life together where they let off before the sacrifices began. Some were able to put life back together as they never left, but others, although back in the saddle at home, the sacrifices continued because things were not the same, they were not the same. Some took a little time to become the same and, yet others never were the same. The depth of the word sacrifice really did not strike me until I spoke with Mr. Joseph McKinney this past year about his time in the service. He and his wife Betty live here in Coosa County but his children live in several places across the United States, thanks to his career in the service. As a child of a close-knit family, this tugs at my heart-strings. Not that having children living across the United States is a bad thing at all, but because so much is missed out on as the family grows and establishes roots in other areas. I feel that the sacrifice of service life continues.
My father served time in the Army but not during a time of war or as a career military person. I often think of how my life would have been different had he made a career out of the service. My sisters and I may have had lives that look totally different than our lives today. The sacrifices I have made as an educator may not have been sacrifices I would have made had my family been a military family. I am thankful for the stories my father has shared with our family about his time in the military but I am also thankful for the stories the veterans of Coosa County are able to share with their families and others, especially during a special time of year when we honor the men and women who have served.
Our plans in life may have been very different, but the appointment of our paths crossing was definitely purposed, if just for an introduction. Share your stories with family and friends. Leave a legacy that reflects a story of sacrifices, a labor of love and a tribute to the best country in the world. Today, Central Elementary will celebrate the veterans of Coosa County and surrounding areas. We would love to have all veterans who are able to attend the program in the Central High School gym beginning at 9:00.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

He and his wife Betty live here in Coosa County but his children live in several places across the United States, thanks to his career in the service. As a child of a close-knit family, this tugs at my heart-strings. Not that having children living across the United States is a bad thing at all, but because so much is missed out on as the family grows and establishes roots in other areas. I feel that the sacrifice of service life continues.
My father served time in the Army but not during a time of war or as a career military person. I often think of how my life would have been different had he made a career out of the service. My sisters and I may have had lives that look totally different than our lives today. The sacrifices I have made as an educator may not have been sacrifices I would have made had my family been a military family. I am thankful for the stories my father has shared with our family about his time in the military but I am also thankful for the stories the veterans of Coosa County are able to share with their families and others, especially during a special time of year when we honor the men and women who have served.
Our plans in life may have been very different, but the appointment of our paths crossing was definitely purposed, if just for an introduction. Share your stories with family and friends. Leave a legacy that reflects a story of sacrifices, a labor of love and a tribute to the best country in the world. Today, Central Elementary will celebrate the veterans of Coosa County and surrounding areas. We would love to have all veterans who are able to attend the program in the Central High School gym beginning at 9:00.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

I would like to begin this article thanking the veterans of Coosa County. I attended the Town of Rockford‚Äôs celebration last Saturday. It was such an honor to not only be among five World War II Coosa Countians, but also many other veterans who made sacrifices for our country. The depth of sacrifice truly cannot be measured. I wonder if many of us truly think about ALL of the sacrifices that are made in order to serve our wonderful country. post_text: Please read and share!
shared_text:
Coosa County School System
November 8, 2019 at 10:17 PM ¬∑

A Note from the Superintendent of Education
If you are in education or know anything about Halloween week in a school setting, you know this can be a challenging week, especially for elementary teachers. Many students begin bringing and eating candy throughout the week due to all of the outside festivities they attend. There is nothing like a ‚Äúsweet‚Äù challenge during school week. However, our teachers survived, as they always do, and students were instructed. I‚Äôm sure there will be some review time built in for next week just to ensure the students understood the information.
I read an article this week about the six takeaways from Alabama‚Äôs school report cards. Based on the article, Alabama is showing improvement. That is a good sign. For Coosa County, we definitely gained in the area of academic growth. This is an exceptional sign. Some students in the system are not performing at grade level, but the growth that is reflected is encouraging for our system. I have always been a believer in meeting the student where they are and moving them forward. With standards being rigorous, it has been difficult to see how much students are moving toward grade level because growth has not been a part of the report card until recently. With the growth measure, students who may not be performing at grade level reflect the hard work that is put into instruction on a daily basis by the teachers.
In the past, the elementary school used a visual to place student names on various colored sticky notes indicating as to where the proficiency was for the student who entered a grade level at the beginning of the school year. For each benchmark session, the student‚Äôs sticky note was moved according to the growth shown in the visual chart. As teachers, the conversation was always ‚ÄúWOW, I wish everyone could see the level where this child entered my classroom and how they have grown‚Äù. Now, the hard work is definitely reflected in the reports for the state. Neither the instruction nor struggles end, but I feel teachers can have more gratification through the growth model addition. As teachers, we all appreciate confirmation of the hard work that is put in to each day. One of my favorite quotes is from a Dr. Seuss book. ‚ÄúAnd will you succeed? Yes, you will indeed, ninety-eight and three fourths percent guaranteed.‚Äù The next portion of the book says ‚ÄúKID, YOU‚ÄôLL MOVE MOUNTAINS!‚Äù I would like to add ‚ÄúTEACHERS, YOU MOVE MOUNTAINS DAY AFTER DAY SO THE STUDENTS CAN SUCCEED NINETY-EIGHT AND THREE FOURTHS PERCENT GUARANTEED!‚Äù With an overall county academic growth of 80.73%, gaps are closing but of course there is more to work to be done.
The ACT scores were released this past week. This past year, 48 students were tested with an overall composite of 17.1 reported for the Coosa County School District. The state composite score for 2019 was 18.9. The five-year trend for Coosa County reflects a variance from 15.9 to 17.2. While the state five-year trend has been steady at 19.1 until the drop this year. All Coosa County eleventh grade students are tested in the spring on ACT plus writing. Students planning to attend college take advantage of other national testing days and work to improve scores in English, Mathematics, Reading and Science. ACT has recently changed policy to include students taking only one area on the assessment, if desired. This will be a great opportunity for students to focus on one area of improvement at a time. Benchmark for each area includes English Composition: 18, Mathematics: 22, Reading: 22, and Science: 23. I look forward to seeing the results of this change for our students.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

Coosa County School System
November 8, 2019 at 10:17 PM ¬∑

A Note from the Superintendent of Education
If you are in education or know anything about Halloween week in a school setting, you know this can be a challenging week, especially for elementary teachers. Many students begin bringing and eating candy throughout the week due to all of the outside festivities they attend. There is nothing like a ‚Äúsweet‚Äù challenge during school week. However, our teachers survived, as they always do, and students were instructed. I‚Äôm sure there will be some review time built in for next week just to ensure the students understood the information.
I read an article this week about the six takeaways from Alabama‚Äôs school report cards. Based on the article, Alabama is showing improvement. That is a good sign. For Coosa County, we definitely gained in the area of academic growth. This is an exceptional sign. Some students in the system are not performing at grade level, but the growth that is reflected is encouraging for our system. I have always been a believer in meeting the student where they are and moving them forward. With standards being rigorous, it has been difficult to see how much students are moving toward grade level because growth has not been a part of the report card until recently. With the growth measure, students who may not be performing at grade level reflect the hard work that is put into instruction on a daily basis by the teachers.
In the past, the elementary school used a visual to place student names on various colored sticky notes indicating as to where the proficiency was for the student who entered a grade level at the beginning of the school year. For each benchmark session, the student‚Äôs sticky note was moved according to the growth shown in the visual chart. As teachers, the conversation was always ‚ÄúWOW, I wish everyone could see the level where this child entered my classroom and how they have grown‚Äù. Now, the hard work is definitely reflected in the reports for the state. Neither the instruction nor struggles end, but I feel teachers can have more gratification through the growth model addition. As teachers, we all appreciate confirmation of the hard work that is put in to each day. One of my favorite quotes is from a Dr. Seuss book. ‚ÄúAnd will you succeed? Yes, you will indeed, ninety-eight and three fourths percent guaranteed.‚Äù The next portion of the book says ‚ÄúKID, YOU‚ÄôLL MOVE MOUNTAINS!‚Äù I would like to add ‚ÄúTEACHERS, YOU MOVE MOUNTAINS DAY AFTER DAY SO THE STUDENTS CAN SUCCEED NINETY-EIGHT AND THREE FOURTHS PERCENT GUARANTEED!‚Äù With an overall county academic growth of 80.73%, gaps are closing but of course there is more to work to be done.
The ACT scores were released this past week. This past year, 48 students were tested with an overall composite of 17.1 reported for the Coosa County School District. The state composite score for 2019 was 18.9. The five-year trend for Coosa County reflects a variance from 15.9 to 17.2. While the state five-year trend has been steady at 19.1 until the drop this year. All Coosa County eleventh grade students are tested in the spring on ACT plus writing. Students planning to attend college take advantage of other national testing days and work to improve scores in English, Mathematics, Reading and Science. ACT has recently changed policy to include students taking only one area on the assessment, if desired. This will be a great opportunity for students to focus on one area of improvement at a time. Benchmark for each area includes English Composition: 18, Mathematics: 22, Reading: 22, and Science: 23. I look forward to seeing the results of this change for our students.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶

This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶
text:
A Note from the Superintendent of Education
If you are in education or know anything about Halloween week in a school setting, you know this can be a challenging week, especially for elementary teachers. Many students begin bringing and eating candy throughout the week due to all of the outside festivities they attend. There is nothing like a ‚Äúsweet‚Äù challenge during school week. However, our teachers survived, as they always do, and students were instructed. I‚Äôm sure there will be some review time built in for next week just to ensure the students understood the information.
I read an article this week about the six takeaways from Alabama‚Äôs school report cards. Based on the article, Alabama is showing improvement. That is a good sign. For Coosa County, we definitely gained in the area of academic growth. This is an exceptional sign. Some students in the system are not performing at grade level, but the growth that is reflected is encouraging for our system. I have always been a believer in meeting the student where they are and moving them forward. With standards being rigorous, it has been difficult to see how much students are moving toward grade level because growth has not been a part of the report card until recently. With the growth measure, students who may not be performing at grade level reflect the hard work that is put into instruction on a daily basis by the teachers.
In the past, the elementary school used a visual to place student names on various colored sticky notes indicating as to where the proficiency was for the student who entered a grade level at the beginning of the school year. For each benchmark session, the student‚Äôs sticky note was moved according to the growth shown in the visual chart. As teachers, the conversation was always ‚ÄúWOW, I wish everyone could see the level where this child entered my classroom and how they have grown‚Äù. Now, the hard work is definitely reflected in the reports for the state. Neither the instruction nor struggles end, but I feel teachers can have more gratification through the growth model addition. As teachers, we all appreciate confirmation of the hard work that is put in to each day. One of my favorite quotes is from a Dr. Seuss book. ‚ÄúAnd will you succeed? Yes, you will indeed, ninety-eight and three fourths percent guaranteed.‚Äù The next portion of the book says ‚ÄúKID, YOU‚ÄôLL MOVE MOUNTAINS!‚Äù I would like to add ‚ÄúTEACHERS, YOU MOVE MOUNTAINS DAY AFTER DAY SO THE STUDENTS CAN SUCCEED NINETY-EIGHT AND THREE FOURTHS PERCENT GUARANTEED!‚Äù With an overall county academic growth of 80.73%, gaps are closing but of course there is more to work to be done.
The ACT scores were released this past week. This past year, 48 students were tested with an overall composite of 17.1 reported for the Coosa County School District. The state composite score for 2019 was 18.9. The five-year trend for Coosa County reflects a variance from 15.9 to 17.2. While the state five-year trend has been steady at 19.1 until the drop this year. All Coosa County eleventh grade students are tested in the spring on ACT plus writing. Students planning to attend college take advantage of other national testing days and work to improve scores in English, Mathematics, Reading and Science. ACT has recently changed policy to include students taking only one area on the assessment, if desired. This will be a great opportunity for students to focus on one area of improvement at a time. Benchmark for each area includes English Composition: 18, Mathematics: 22, Reading: 22, and Science: 23. I look forward to seeing the results of this change for our students.
Once again, as the Instructional Leader of the Coosa County School System, with the support of all stakeholders: administrators, faculty, staff, students, businesses and community, I will promote an environment that supports the diverse needs of all students. This will include, but not be limited to, effectively planning for system improvements by collecting, analyzing and interpreting data, problem-solving, and allocating resources to address the most critical needs identified. Additionally, I will seek supports to enhance the unique and diverse characteristics of the county by creating and sustaining opportunities for more school-community relations. I am proud to call Coosa County my home and especially proud to lead the efforts in moving the Coosa County School System forward. Stay tuned‚Ä¶
